name: Barbados
notes_H1: Original "Barbados has established a COVID-19 information hotline that can be reached at 246-536-4500. Archived Source: /web/20200402213119/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ Information is being posted on the Government Information Service website, with a special web page dedicated to COVID-19. Archived Source: /web/20200402213250/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020-fbclidiwar32cxrvq5zqfy0msm6nybss1_90a-nygoo3isvesndcghk-wagaik1dz48/"   Dowling - Updating with new source since the two two above seem unrelated. Jan 22 report from Barbados Ministry of Health: https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/health-ministry-on-alert-for-new-coronavirus/
notes_H2: "The Ministry of Health and Wellness continues to appeal to members of the public to get tested for the COVID-19 virus whether they believe that   they are symptomatic or not." As per the sources, "PCR tests are available at government facilities for no charge."      https://web.archive.org/web/20210403100508/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/health-ministry-get-tested-for-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210403102203/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel, and there is no curfew in place. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200830212325/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Public schools resumed with online classes on January 18th. Barbados Community College also returned to online classes on January 22nd.  sources:  https://archive.vn/h9AXR  https://archive.vn/Jzwkf
notes_H6: Face masks now required in all public spaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207205308/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/download/official-gazette-february-1-2021-part-a-no-14/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207191256/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/highlights-of-curfew-directives-from-feb-3-to-17/
notes_E2: No evidence of a policy change.  "Banks are now working with individual borrowers as needed on further repayment extensions."  source:  https://archive.vn/bZZSM
notes_E1: There is no change in this policy.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402214146/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/further-support-for-adopt-our-families-programme/
notes_C3: From January 2nd until January 14th, no person shall host or attend:  a party;  (b) a recreational or competitive sporting event;  (c) a banquet, ball, dance or reception;  (d) a meeting of a fraternal society, private or social club or   civic association or organization;  (e) the social event known as  (i) "a bus crawl"; or  (ii) "a lime";  (f) a karaoke event;  (g) a picnic; or  (h) a bus or other vehicular excursion  source:  https://archive.vn/kOBRg
notes_C6: Curfew in place between midnight and 5 am beginning on December 31st.  source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210103175958/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/download/emergency-management-covid-19-protocol-no-4-amendment/
notes_C8: Barbados Ministry of Tourism’s updated travel protocols came into effect on August 3rd.   These protocols state that “persons from High-Risk countries with a valid negative COVID-19 PCR test result will be quarantined at a designated holding hotel or approved villa at their own expense, or free of charge at a government facility, and will be monitored daily for the onset of symptoms. These persons will be quarantined for a period of 14 days with an option to take a second COVID-19 PCR test between 5-7 days after the last test accepted by the Ministry of Health and Wellness. Persons will typically be released once the test result is negative.” “High-Risk: Includes USA, Brazil, India, Mexico, Argentina, Peru, Colombia, South Africa, Indonesia, Philippines and Russia.”  Countries not classified as High-Risk, unless within the “Bubble”, which includes “Saint Lucia, St. Kitts & Nevis, Grenada, Dominica and St. Vincent & The Grenadines”, are required to take a COVID-19 PCR test prior to or on arrival.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200830211314/https://www.visitbarbados.org/covid-19-travel-guidelines-2020
notes_H8: First mention of a policy or measures for the protection of elderly in relation to Covid-19:  No more than 1 person at a time should visit a patient in a nursing home or senior citizens’ home    https://archive.vn/Tw3wF  https://1drv.ms/b/s!AjvFoN9mD2CwkZd19yyJawSWTntmaw?e=LFQ9GY
notes_C2: The Government has decided to impose more restrictive measures during the holidays. Only essential services can be open from 05:00 am to 09:00 pm on these days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210401160758/https://pmo.gov.bb/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/Emergency-Management-Covid-19-Curfew-No.-7-Directive-2021.pdf
notes_C4: From January 2nd until January 14th:  "A person may only visit a beach or a park for the purpose of   swimming or exercise and, in the case of a group of persons, such  persons shall be from the same household and shall not exceed 10  persons."  source:  https://archive.vn/kOBRg
notes_H7: A,B,C  Vaccines available to those above 70 years and those age 18-69 with non-communicable diseases beginning February 17th. Frontline workers were initially the only group receiving the vaccine. The Oxford Astra Zeneca vaccine is being administered.  source: https://archive.vn/bamSy  https://archive.vn/wT0Qo
notes_H3: "The Ministry has initiated the process of contact tracing to identify every individual who came in close contact with all cases and will quarantine such persons for 14 days. They will also be tested for COVID-19 if they become symptomatic."  Archived Source: /web/20200402230214/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/two-new-covid-19-cases-in-barbados/
notes_C5: The Barbados government published the 'Emergency Management (COVID-19)  Protocol (No. 4) Directive, 2020' on 29th October 2020. Measures outlined will apply between the 29th October, 2020 and the 27th March, 2021.    While the measures allow public transport to operate with its authorised number of seated passengers, only half the number of authorised standing passengers are allowed on the vehicle.    https://drive.google.com/file/d/120tlIBURJq4vvzEgG4UR5khtz-N9jxXJ/view

name: Brunei
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health has a website with all relevant information on Coronavirus. It also brings statements to the population often.  Campaign website: /web/20200404203230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19.aspx  According to this source, campaign started on January 6: /web/20200404203313/https://sites.google.com/site/weechiankoh/home/Covid-19
notes_H2: Information from Ministry on Health on general charges for RT-PCR tests for citizen or foreign travelers, effective August 14, 2020.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201219023333/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/Swab%20charges_website_14082020.pdf
notes_C7: Members of the public are still required to comply with physical distancing guidelines even when businesses and public services return to full operations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729111541/https://thescoop.co/2020/07/23/brunei-proceeds-to-final-phase-of-de-escalation-plan-on-july-27/
notes_C1: All schools, including tertiary education institutions, can resume the “normal academic term” in the final phase of reopening from July 27, the education minister said.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729111541/https://thescoop.co/2020/07/23/brunei-proceeds-to-final-phase-of-de-escalation-plan-on-july-27/
notes_H6: “It is mandatory for those serving food, whether in fast food outlets or restaurants. They are the ones who should be using face masks.” Students it is recommended, and it will be mandatory during an outbreak in an area  https://web.archive.org/web/20200830144253/https://borneobulletin.com.bn/2020/06/face-masks-mandatory-for-food-servers-not-for-students/
notes_E2: Deferment measures have expired. See the International Monetary Fund's section on Brunei, last updated April 2, 2021.    See IMF's website, archived at http://web.archive.org/web/20210406210001/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: No Income support provided as of now, it was provided until June 2020  Refer to:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200425202332/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/
notes_C3: Six types of premises will be allowed to reopen on May 16, including restaurants, gyms and sports facilities, driving schools as well as stalls and markets as part of the government’s “de-escalation plan” to ease coronavirus restrictions. While eateries, markets and sports facilities are now allowed to reopen, they are only permitted host 30 percent of their capacity at any one time.  /web/20200521022736/https://thescoop.co/2020/05/01/covid-19-live-updates-3/
notes_C8: Moving the code from 2 to 4, as entry into Brunei remains severely limited for foreigners from all countries, including Singapore (which has a Reciprocal Green Lane' agreement with Brunei - however, visitors from Singapore are only allowed in on essential business trips and via the same Entry Travel Pass requirements imposed on all other foreigners) except those entering for essential purposes (see Entry Travel Pass requirements).    Per the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory,    "The Bruneian government has imposed an entry ban on all foreign visitors (non-Brunei citizens/non-Brunei permanent residents), including transit passengers, from 24 March 2020 until further notice. Foreign visitors seeking to enter Brunei must receive prior approval from the Brunei Department of Immigration and National Registration."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 5 Mar, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.  Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.  Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Minister’s Office.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.    Per the Ministry of Health,   From 20 March 2020, all passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam  through any points of entry are required to undergo mandatory selfisolation for 14 days at a government-designated facility immediately  upon arrival to the country.  i) Self-isolation at private homes are not permitted.  ii) This include all visitors and foreign workers arriving in the  country.  iii) All foreign nationals including foreign workers arriving in the  country are required to bear fully the cost of mandatory selfisolation (including accommodation and meals) and laboratory  test for SARS-CoV-2 ($1000 per test).  iv) Foreign workers must submit special entry application for foreign  workers before arriving in Brunei Darussalam.     Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  • Essential business travel (including official travel)  • Students  • Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  • Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory, archived at https://archive.vn/pQ2MH  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/fnAPh  See the Ministry of Health's guidelines on travel, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/mpd9geybded3b1h/BRN-undated-Guidelines_Travel.pdf  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf
notes_H8: Brunei Ministry of Health: "It is advisable for senior citizens and patients with chronic diseases to take extra precautions, such as avoiding crowded places and public transportation, in addition to daily precautionary measures."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200330114345/http://moh.gov.bn:80/SitePages/FAQCOVID19.aspx
notes_C2: From 17th August 2020 onwards, Cinemas will proceed to the third stage of reopening, operating at 80 percent of its full capacity compared to 60 percent in the second phase, and children will be allowed to go to cinemas. Cinemagoers must be kept one seat apart but family members can sit together.  Buffet restaurants will reopen, however only restaurant employees who wear protective face masks can serve food to the patrons. There is no capacity limit for dine-in at restaurants, cafés and food courts since the fourth phase of de-escalation plan took effect.  indoor and outdoor playgrounds as well as game arcades can operate at 60 percent of their normal capacity.  Museums, exhibition galleries and public libraries will also move to the final stage of reopening, hosting a maximum number of 100 people at a time as opposed to the previous 70 people.  For senior citizen centres, attendance is capped at 80 percent at a specific time – an increase from 60 percent.  Under the third phase of de-escalation plan, swimming pools are allowed to operate every day with no age restrictions and can accommodate 80 percent of its total capacity.  Visitors of swimming pools can use the facilities up to two hours a day.  The ministry has also increased the number of people allowed to train for team sports from 10 to 15 people.  Special needs centres and childcare facilities will be able to resume full operations next Monday as part of the fourth phase of de-escalation plan, said the minister of culture, youth and sports. Children of all ages can return to childcare centres, except those who display flu symptoms such as fever or are at high risk of developing a severe infection.  Special needs centres are also open to all, excluding those with chronic diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200817154003/https://thescoop.co/2020/08/13/govt-announces-further-easing-of-covid-19-curbs/
notes_C4: On 13th August 2020, the Government raised the limit of people at public and social gatherings from 100 to 200 people at a time.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200817154003/https://thescoop.co/2020/08/13/govt-announces-further-easing-of-covid-19-curbs/
notes_H7: A:    Vaccines used: Oxford-AstraZeneca (AZD1222/ChAdOx1 nCoV-19); Sinopharm (BBIBP-CorV)    Following yesterday's (2nd April) joint WHO-Brunei press release that Brunei has received 24,000 doses of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine via the COVAX facility, Brunei has started vaccination, where "vaccine shots will be given to around 2,000 local frontliners, including health facility staff, uniformed personnel from the Royal Brunei Armed Forces, Royal Brunei Police Force, as well as those involved in quarantines and immigration post control affairs [in the first phase]".    According to the Bruneian Minister of Health, Haji Awang Mohammad Isham, the ministry "deployed Sinopharm and AstraZeneca vaccines for the first day of the national vaccination program in the country". The Sultan of Brunei has also taken his first dose of the vaccine (although not specified which), and "has consented for the rolling-out of the national vaccination program".    The morning session saw more than 340 people received the first dose of COVID-19 vaccine nationwide, with the total tally at 754 by the end of the day.    According to Xinhua (https://archive.vn/P1su4), emergency use authorisation has also been given to the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine (tozinameran), which has not arrived nor been used yet.    Additionally, per the US Embassy in Brunei,    COVID-19 Vaccine Information:  Has the government of Brunei approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes.  Are vaccines available in Brunei Darussalam for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes.  Which vaccines are available in Brunei Darussalam?  Oxford-AstraZeneca and Sinopharm while the Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Novavax are expected at a later date.  The COVID-19 vaccine will be provided free of charge to citizens and residents residing in Brunei Darussalam.  Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for information to Brunei Darussalam Vaccination Strategy.    COVAX announcements:  See the WHO press release, archived at https://archive.vn/gTsEW  See the Ministry of Health press release, archived at https://archive.vn/TlsgY    Start of vaccination announcements/press releases:  See Ministry of Health's announcement, archived at https://archive.vn/divhM (in Malay)  See Xinhua's report, archived at https://archive.vn/Ae3w2  See the US Embassy in Brunei's page on COVID-19, archived at https://archive.vn/Zhhlx
notes_H3: It is also a legal requirement for all visitors and residents in Brunei to use the contact-tracing app BruHealth every time they enter/exit a public place. https://web.archive.org/web/20201025200552/https://thescoop.co/2020/10/23/coronavirus-one-new-imported-case-but-no-local-transmission-for-169-days/

name: Bhutan
notes_H1: Ministry of Health in a series of Facebook posts informs citizens of preventation methods regarding COVID. From thereon out communicates daily on preventative measures, hence coded as 2G; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607161958/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086568319607&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162003/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086571652940&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162010/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086611652936&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162017/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086654986265&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162019/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086664986264&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162416/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086748319589&set=a.771480979580187  https://web.archive.org/web/20200607162414/https://www.facebook.com/photo?fbid=2884086714986259&set=a.771480979580187
notes_H2: Officials are also performing random COVID-19 testing for travelers, students, teachers, transporters, and business personnel every two weeks.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316112730/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/452441/bhutan-authorities-maintain-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-travel-controls-as-of-march-8-update-23
notes_C7: All non-essential and leisure travels within the country are restricted. Movements in groups, within the towns and communities are also discouraged.     Road Safety and Transport Authority is instructed to design and implement strategies for passengers using public transports to maintain physical distance.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210330091444/https://kuenselonline.com/press-release-from-prime-ministers-office/
notes_C1: All schools will open as scheduled by the education ministry. Random testing for students and teachers will be carried out every two weeks. Health focal persons have been identified to monitor compliance and surveillance on campus.  (Press release on Unlocking Thimphu and beyond starting Monday (February 1, 2021)-PMO)  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
notes_H6: "As essential health services are key for the sustenance of life and in an attempt to ease access to such services, the National COVID-19 Task Force today approved a protocol for availing essential health services during lockdowns.  The approved protocol will henceforth be applied during all lockdowns irrespective of their scale and magnitude.  The Ministry of Health urges all Bhutanese to kindly follow the attached protocol for availing the services through the essential health focal points which have been identified for all the 20 districts.  However, please note that everyone availing these services particularly in the health facilities should strictly abide by the following preventive measures:  1. Practice good physical distancing,  2. Wear a face mask at all times and  3. Wash hands frequently with soap and water or use a alcohol based hand rub from time to time."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201107135037/https://www.facebook.com/MoHBhutan/posts/3382997755095150
notes_E2: The Royal Monetary Authority (RMA) is working with the financial institutions to defer the loan repayment period and waive interest payments for three months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607175452/https://www.royalkidu.bt/royal-address/index.html
notes_E1: The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.  Investments in GovTech is allowing Bhutan to reap benefits during COVID-19 including fast disbursement of cash relief funds.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208102716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  The Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu was launched on 14 April 2020 to provide income support to individuals whose livelihoods were affected because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Between April and September 2020, Nu.1.2 billion was granted to over 33,000 beneficiaries and over 14,000 children.    The Relief Kidu has been extended for three months, from October to December 2020. Individuals who applied for or received Kidu in Phase I and/or Phase II need to re-apply for further assessments. Applications are also open to new applicants who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic.  Who is eligible?  Bhutanese who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic and are currently residing in Bhutan are eligible for the Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu. The displaced group includes those who have been laid off, placed on unpaid leave or on reduced pay from businesses *** as well as self-employed individuals *** who have lost their earnings either partially or completely.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208103817/https://royalkidu.bt/
notes_C3: Gatherings for religious purposes are discouraged, prompted by the fact that countries have experienced outbreaks from such events.     Gathering at any social events like birthday, wedding or promotion are disallowed.     Picnics or similar outdoor functions are prohibited.    All congregations at work, official dinners, functions or gatherings at workplace eateries are discouraged.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210330091444/https://kuenselonline.com/press-release-from-prime-ministers-office/
notes_C6: the battle is only half won as we continue to sail through the pandemic, that too amid peak winter. We could regress into a situation far more disastrous if we let our guards down today.  Therefore, concerted efforts are being made to heighten surveillance along the borders and entry points with enhanced vigilance and improved operating procedures.  More tests for COVID-19 will be conducted among business communities, drivers, frontliners, students and health workers, while flu clinics will always scan for the early signs of the disease. Additional mobile flu clinics will be introduced in busy public places and certain points along the highways.  Above all, we are anticipating the roll out of the nationwide COVID-19 vaccination program that will protect our people and enable us to prevent the outbreak of the disease as we venture forward.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/
notes_C8: Bhutanese travelling abroad must seek prior approval from Ministry of Foreign Affairs even before they start processing formalities for the travel.  Bhutan’s borders are currently closed to foreign nationals. The Royal Government of Bhutan has not yet specified when the country will re-open to foreign visitors.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210330091444/https://kuenselonline.com/press-release-from-prime-ministers-office/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210330092059/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/entry-requirements
notes_H8: On May 21st, the Bhutan government published the first "Guidance on Prevention & Control of COVID-19 in Elderly People"  to prevent the spread of COVID-19 infection to the elderly people (60 years and above). The guidance includes recommendations to health care workers to periodically conduct medical check-ups on all elderly people (~18% of the population of Bhutan) at home and to discourage "All elderly people [...] from visiting health facilities, unless it is an emergency or if they have regular appointments like Dialysis, Chemotherapy etc.." It also lists a number of recommendations to the elderly itself as well as to caregivers. As those recommendations include "staying home," "hygiene," and "visitor restrictions," this qualifies as a 1G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210129193925/http://www.moh.gov.bt/wp-content/uploads/ict-files/2020/05/Guidance-on-Prevention-Control-of-COVID-19-in-Elderly-People-1st-edition-1.docx
notes_C2: All movie theatres, snooker rooms and video parlours should be closed.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210330091444/https://kuenselonline.com/press-release-from-prime-ministers-office/
notes_C4: Gathering at any social events like birthday, wedding or promotion are disallowed.   Picnics or similar outdoor functions are prohibited.    All congregations at work, official dinners, functions or gatherings at workplace eateries are discouraged.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210330091444/https://kuenselonline.com/press-release-from-prime-ministers-office/
notes_H7: Vaccine: Covishield  Roll-out plan updates: all citizens above 15 years' old are eligible for vaccine registration.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316113559/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/03-03-21-information-series-on-covid-19-vaccines-moh/
notes_H3: Contact tracing of the 76-year-old corona positive patient from the US was immediately set in place (on March 6), covering his itinerary including places visited and people he had associated with. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607153628/http://www.moh.gov.bt/third-batch-of-17-people-tested-negative/; https://web.archive.org/web/20200607153633/https://www.drukair.com.sg/news/covid-19-updates-bhutan-travel-announcement/

name: Botswana

See the press release:   https://archive.vn/VfzZo
notes_H3: CONTACT TRACING   Purpose  This document provides the steps needed to systematically monitor persons at high risk  for COVID-19 infection, as well as to conduct contact tracing of COVID-19 cases in  Botswana, and contacts whom they may have exposed to the disease. In conjunction  with active case finding and testing, and in synergy with other measures such as physical  distancing, contact tracing is recommended in all transmission scenarios.  According to current knowledge, COVID 19 is passed from one person to another primarily  through droplet transmission. People in close contact with COVID-19 cases are at high  risk of being infected with COVID-19, and, if infected, may also transmit the infection to  others. This guideline details how once a COVID-19 case has been identified, the Ministry  of Health and Wellness (MoHW) through District Health Management Teams (DHMT) and  other implementing partners will track, trace and manage people who may have been  exposed to COVID-19.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923115019/https://covid19portal.gov.org.bw/sites/default/files/2020-05/COVID-19-Contact-Tracing-Guideline.pdf
notes_C5: It appears that public transport is still running but that COVID-19 protocols must be adhered to public transport operators, such as not permitting anyone to use public transport without a face mask, cleaning the interior and exterior 2-3 times a day, and using hand sanitiser or washing hands etc.     See the press release from the Government, archived: http://archive.vn/WsNAi

name: Central African Republic
notes_H1: Since February, seeing no updates on media or standard reporting sites on COVID. Changing status. New president is in place on 3/31/21 - with elections over this may change https://archive.vn/6YKfa
notes_H2: The Central African Republic’s authorities have adopted a response plan for the health sector and enacted social distancing measures, including the closing of borders, schools, and most public establishments, a ban on meetings of more than 15 people, and restrictions on the movement of people from Bangui.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200514181918/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    14 March 2020  WHO and the Ministry of Health and Population have already started raising awareness among the population on COVID-19, things to know, the importance of not giving in to panic and d '' observe the simple steps to prevent the disease, namely: wash your hands regularly with soap and water, cough or sneeze into the crease of the elbow or into a handkerchief to be thrown away immediately in a closed bin, keep a distance social at least one meter, avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth or call the alert number of the Ministry of Health and Population, 1212, to report suspected cases.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200515205656/https://www.afro.who.int/fr/news/la-republique-centrafricaine-rca-declare-un-premier-cas-de-covid-19    18 March 2020  A risk communication plan was developed for the Central African Republic.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200515204155/https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/331487/SITREP_COVID-19_WHOAFRO_20200318-eng.pdf    26 March 2020  An initial national prevention and response plan, focusing on public interventions was released in March and activities are ongoing. Prevention measures announced by the President on 26 March include the temporary but ongoing closure of schools, bars, airport and borders. School closures affect over 1,370,000 pupils.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200514103210/https://reliefweb.int/report/central-african-republic/unicef-central-african-republic-covid-19-situation-report-no-1-1-15    26 March 2020  Guidelines set forth by the government to contain the coronavirus range from systematic checks at border entry points and the self-isolation of passengers from countries at risk to mass communication initiatives and the prohibition of mass gatherings and movements.     Reinforcement measures were announced by the Head of State Faustin-Archange Touadera thereafter: limiting air traffic operations at the M’poko International Airport to a few commercial flights, humanitarian flights, cargo flights, aircrafts in difficulty and for technical stopovers without disembarkation; restrictions on the operation of educational establishments, places of recreation conducting mourning and marriage ceremonies; movement restrictions from Bangui to the provinces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200514185240/https://peacekeeping.un.org/en/covid-19-cases-grow-car-minusca-supports-government-urgent-response-to-halt-virus-spread    17 April 2020  The MINUSCA Rwanda Contingent has donated a COVID-19 screening device to the Central African Republic (CAR). The machine will accelerate testing of suspected cases of infection as the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the country reached 94 over the past few days.  https://www.africanews.com/2020/05/09/coronavirus-rwanda-donates-covid-19-testing-device-to-central-african-republic-car-by-maria-kabatanya//    23 April 2020   The World Bank approved a grant of $7.5 million from the International Development Association (IDA)* to help the Central African Republic respond to the threat posed by the Coronavirus outbreak and strengthen national systems for public health preparedness.    The COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Project will provide immediate support to the Central African Republic to prevent the spread of COVID-19 through containment strategies and by strengthening the public health emergency response for a potential outbreak. The project will bring in essential medical supplies and drugs, testing kits, personal protective equipment for frontline health workers, and water and hygiene supplies for the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200514105511/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2020/04/23/the-central-african-republic-to-strengthen-preparedness-and-response-to-coronavirus
notes_C7: "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026125315/https://cf.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: "After almost seven months, pupils across the Central African Republic started to return to the classrooms on 19 October 2020 for the beginning of the school year 2020-2021. Schools were closed countrywide at the end of March as a measure to contain the spread of Covid-19. Some classes resumed in July and continued through to September, but only the three levels in an examination year, allowing pupils to proceed to the next class. Meanwhile, the children in the other nine levels without a year-end exam remained at home."    ===   While there has been an effort to maintain hygiene standards, it has proven very difficult in the usually very crowded classrooms. I am therefore coding this as "0" rather than "1G" as I believe it reflects the situation on the ground more closely.   I am also providing a source, describing the difficulties in maintaining the best hygiene standards:"The humanitarian community has also been supporting the Ministry of Education to prepare a safe return to school in the wake of Covid-19. Funds from the Global Partnership for Education, managed by UNICEF in the Central African Republic, allowed the purchase of hand washing facilities, soaps and similar items that are distributed to schools across the country. Humanitarian actors have also purchased facial masks for teachers and pupils. The Education Cluster has been supporting the Ministry of Education in elaborating a protocol, defining the hygiene standards at school in the context of the pandemic.    However, despite great efforts, schools in the Central African Republic are likely not in a position to respond effectively to the requirements of the pandemic. In the current context, where many schools are dilapidated and where one teacher looks on average after 113 children, respecting physical distance during classes is naturally difficult, to say the least. Respecting Covid-19 barrier measures would imply the construction of hundreds of new classrooms and the recruitment and training of thousands of teachers."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123185702/https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/car/card/3uAzeWsox8/

notes_H3: An aggressive contact-tracing regime has been central to many African countries’ achievements in slowing the spread of Covid-19. Drawing on experience responding to previous disease outbreaks and extensive networks of community health workers, among other assets, countries have been able to lean on robust tracing regimes and stringent isolation policies to control transmission despite limitations in testing. Important lessons on contact tracing can be learned from effective strategies deployed in Africa, especially as governments around the world seek to loosen mobility restrictions and safely reopen their economies.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404074735/https://institute.global/advisory/insights-africas-covid-19-response-contact-tracing    One difficulty lies in the multitude of villages to be served, and there is still a lack of mobile oxygen units, respirators as well as training in contact-tracing techniques. Once again, civil society seeks national and international solidarity from donors, companies and international organisations and institutions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210404074822/https://www.fern.org/publications-insight/covid-19-in-the-central-african-republic-civil-societys-response-to-the-pandemic-2212/

notes_E1: The Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy (CEWS) supports employers that are hardest hit by the pandemic, and protect the jobs Canadians depend on. The subsidy generally covers 75% of an employee's wages – up to $847 per week - for employers of all sizes and across all sectors who have suffered a drop in gross revenues of at least 15% in March, and 30% in April and May. The program will be in place for a 12-week period, from March 15 to June 6, 2020.  Also, the Canadian government will provide a taxable benefit of $2,000 every 4 weeks for up to 16 weeks to eligible workers who have lost their income due to COVID-19 under the Canadian Emergency Response Benefit.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200318220215/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html Then go to businesses

notes_H7: On 20 January 2021, Indigenous Services Canada announced: “The rollout of the vaccines to many First Nations, Inuit, and Métis communities has started. Vaccine administration continues within communities, thanks to the commitment of Indigenous leadership and health experts, and federal, provincial, Indigenous collaboration, including on logistics and data sharing. To date vaccination has begun in 169 communities for First Nations or Inuit in all provinces and territories except Nova Scotia and PEI.” Covid vaccinations (Pfizer and Moderna) in Canada are being administered to 3 groups -- A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or other health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126020941/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/01/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126024649/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-older-at-risk-federal-inmates-to-receive-shot-sparking-criticism-from/

notes_C5: Effective 6 January, the Office of Premier Blaine Higgs announced that “the entire province of New Brunswick will move to the Orange level... Public Health recommended the move due to the doubling of cases in less than six days … as well as reports of situations where some individuals were not complying with public health measures.” To comply with orange alert rules requiring 1m distancing on public transit, city transit services reduced bus seating capacity to 50% or 15-20 passengers on each bus.     See New Brunswick government websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110192430/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2021.01.0007.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110205043/https://www.saintjohn.ca/news-and-service-updates/saint-john-transit-seating-capacity-reduced-by-covid-19-orange-phase  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110203956/https://www.fredericton.ca/en/transit

name: Switzerland

notes_C7: As of 6 June 2020, there are no more restrictions on workplaces.    The only remaining restrictions are on gatherings in public of more than 30 people, events or demonstrations with more than 300 people and sports competition involving close physical contact.  Keeping a distance, wearing a mask and observing hygiene rules still applies    (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200611185821/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html)
notes_C1: Higher education institutions switched to distance learning from Monday, 2 November 2020.     Classroom teaching is still permitted at compulsory school level and at upper secondary schools (baccalaureate and vocational schools).    This measure was announced on October 28, 2020, and applied on November 2, 2020, for an indefinite period of time.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201109173331/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/das-bag/aktuell/medienmitteilungen.msg-id-80882.html
notes_H6: The requirement for persons over the age of 12 to wear a mask on public transport has been in place since 6 July. From Monday 19 October this will be extended to railway stations including platforms, airports and other publicly accessible public transport areas. As before, persons who are unable to wear a mask for medical reasons are exempt from the requirement.  Masks are now also compulsory in publicly accessible indoor spaces including all shops, shopping centres, banks, post offices, museums, libraries, cinemas, theatres, concert venues, indoor areas of zoos and botanical gardens, restaurants, bars, discos, casinos, hotels (with the exception of guests’ rooms), entrance areas and changing rooms in swimming pools, sports facilities and gyms, doctor’s surgeries, hospitals and places of worship, advisory centres and neighbourhood centres. Masks must also be worn in publicly accessible areas of administrative buildings.  Face masks must also be worn in all schools and higher education establishments, in child-care facilities and in the training areas of sport and fitness centres if part of the centre’s precautionary measures.    https://archive.vn/2fyBb
notes_E2: The measure to protect renters expired on 1 June 2020  "Extension of the deadline for payment arrears by the tenant from 30 today to at least 90 days. However, this only applies to payment arrears that arise in connection with the Federal Council's measures to combat the corona virus. It is also only about rents and ancillary costs that are due between March 13 and May 31, 2020."    (http://web.archive.org/web/20200710220151/https://www.bwo.admin.ch/bwo/de/home/mietrecht/coronavirus.html)    Other measures providing debt/contract relief to families are not known.

notes_C2: Recoded from 3T to 2G because Geneva's local lockdown was softened with the reopening of various activities from 21 November: personal services involving physical contacts such as hairdressers, beauticians, barbers, tattoo artists and therapists.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201207191537/https://www.ge.ch/en/covid-19-restrictions-closures-and-other-measures
notes_C4: ***Recoded from 3T to 4G; national ban on private events with more than 10 people came into effect on October 29, 2020.     See table on easing and tightening of measures, downloadable here:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210129191814/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/massnahmen-des-bundes.html
notes_H7: B,C: Pfizer/BioNTech      Vaccination was started in most cantons on 4 January 2021. Especially vulnerable people are being vaccinated first.   The following people are to be given access to vaccinations first:  * People age 75 and over  * People with chronic diseases of the highest risk, regardless of their age    https://web.archive.org/web/20210109120317/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html
notes_H3: Contact tracing is in the responsibility of the 26 cantons, making it difficult to assess the exact situation.    In terms of policy, it seems that all cantons continued, resumed or set up contact tracing as of 11 May 2020.  See below for a list of references to the cantons for which explicit documentation was found.  Therefore as of 11 May 2020, H2=2.    HOWEVER:   -the capacities are not always sufficient and information on this is documented in later entries  -there is no strong central coordination (the cantons do their own thing)  -although all cantons see it as their duty to implement contact tracing the wording at the federal level only talks about a "recommendation" as in:   "Contact tracing is recommended for all people with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 or for hospitalized people with probable COVID-19. The responsible cantonal agency identifies the close contacts and contacts them."  (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200530165857/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/information-fuer-die-aerzteschaft/contact-tracing.html)    Despite these restrictions, H2=2 seems to reflect the policy of the cantons best. name: Chile
notes_H1: Ministry of health announces COVID response has moved to Phase three, asks all citizens to take self-care measures, quarantines to be respected, handshakes, kisses and the most efficient measure, which is frequent hand washing, to be avoided. Launches government website; https://web.archive.org/web/20200331183753/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/covid-19-ministerio-de-salud-confirma-que-chile-paso-fase-3/
notes_H2: "COVID-19 testing is available at all public and private hospitals/clinics. Anyone may request a test, whether symptomatic or not, though private hospitals and clinics may require an appointment beforehand."  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://cl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Jaime Mañalich, Minister of Health, announced that the Chilean government decrees a total mandatory quarantine for the province of Santiago, the country's capital, and other neighboring communes. The decision will take effect at 10:00 p.m. on Friday, May 15 [/web/20200601192955/https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-52655289]
notes_C1: Since 1 July 2020, schools have reopened in COVID-19 free remote pacific islands of Easter Island and Juan Fernandez archipelago. All other schools remain closed. See UNICEF situation report https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Chile%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20No.2-%2030%20July%202020.pdf AND local news agency Chile Today article, archived https://web.archive.org/web/20201129085624/https://chiletoday.cl/schools-reopen-on-easter-island-with-outbreak-under-control/
notes_H6: 'Its use is mandatory in public and private transport throughout the country, as well as in elevators and places where there are 10 or more people crowded together (for example, health centers, supermarkets, pharmacies, etc.).'  Link -  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221112227/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/plandeaccion/
notes_E2: Still appears to be current   https://web.archive.org/web/20200827131007/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/plandeaccion/#v-pills-planeconoemergencia
notes_E1: "President Piñera signs a project that expands Emergency Family Income to benefit up to 5.6 million people: "It reaches far beyond vulnerable groups and includes the middle class." The initiative, which is part of the Agreement for Social Protection and Job Recovery, extends the benefit to up to $ 100,000 per person.    The program, part of the transversal agreement promoted by the President for social protection and job recovery, changes its design to act as a complement to the current income of the family group. This encompasses both households with no formal income and those with some formal income, and includes families with other benefits such as the employment protection law, unemployment insurance, support for independent workers and people who collect contributory pensions. and non-contributory.    The law adds a fourth month of payment, which will be 80% of income and may go up to 100% if sanitary conditions so warrant."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200702133937/https://prensa.presidencia.cl/comunicado.aspx?id=152600
notes_C3: "All public events with more than 50 people are indefinitely prohibited."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201113065927/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/plandeaccion/
notes_C6: Jaime Mañalich, Minister of Health, announced that the Chilean government decrees a total mandatory quarantine for the province of Santiago, the country's capital, and other neighboring communes. The decision will take effect at 10:00 p.m. on Friday, May 15 [/web/20200601192955/https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-52655289]
notes_C8: "On December 29, the Chilean government announced that starting on December 31, all travelers, including Chileans, foreign residents, accredited diplomats, and foreign tourists, must complete an obligatory 10-day quarantine upon their arrival to Chile.  They will be able to leave quarantine with a negative PCR result based on a test taken on or after the seventh day in quarantine.  Travelers must remain in quarantine while they await their result."    "ATTENTION Travelers coming from UK: Due to the information provided by the United Kingdom authorities, and its epidemiological situation, the Chilean Government has determined, as of Tuesday 22nd December:  - The cancellation of all direct flights between the UK and Chile.  - A ban on entry to all foreign non-legal residents who have been in the UK in the last 14 days.  - The obligation for all Chilean and legal foreign residents on a regular basis entering the country, and who have been in the UK for the last 14 days, to undertake a mandatory 14-day quarantine in Chile."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201221112951/https://cl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: Since March 15, the following protections were added for elderly people.     "To better care for our older adults, who are the highest risk group against COVID-19, the government has decreed the following measures.    - Visits to Long-Stay Establishments for Older Adults will be prohibited, restricting access to strictly necessary people, and hygiene and isolation measures will be strengthened within these establishments.  - The operation of all Day Centers for the elderly throughout the country will be suspended.  - All meetings of clubs and community unions of older adults in the country will be suspended."    http://web.archive.org/web/*/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/plandeaccion/
notes_C2: Jaime Mañalich, Minister of Health, announced that the Chilean government decrees a total mandatory quarantine for the province of Santiago, the country's capital, and other neighboring communes. The decision will take effect at 10:00 p.m. on Friday, May 15 [/web/20200601192955/https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-52655289]
notes_C4: "All public events with more than 50 people are indefinitely prohibited." In certain regions that are in stage 1, they must stay at home, only leaving their house twice a week for purchases or essential procedures.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201113065927/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/plandeaccion/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201113163049/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/pasoapaso/
notes_H7: ABC:    Starting December 24, the Chilean government has started vaccinating "medical personnel from the regions of La Araucanía, Biobío and Magallanes, some of the most affected by the pandemic. As of January 11, 2020, there have been 10, 699 first doses administered.    The Sinovac vaccine is being distributed to adults between 87 and 89 years of age, starting February 4th and to adults between 85 and 86 on Friday, February 5th.     "«As of Monday, March 1, we will incorporate people who are with cancer, over 16 years of age, and who are undergoing treatment with radiotherapy, immunotherapy or chemotherapy , we will also incorporate those people who have an autoimmune disease and are are in treatment with biological therapy and / or small molecules, ”reported the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza, during the balance of the COVID-19 pandemic in the country."    "As of this Monday March 8, more than 89 thousand people with severe or profound disabilities will receive the first dose against Covid-19"    " In the vaccination calendar established by the Ministry of Health, it was specified that from March 15 people in the transport sector can be vaccinated, with which it is expected to inoculate more than 74 thousand drivers of basic taxis, executives, tourism , collectives, school transport and bus drivers. "    "« Today (March 24) a milestone is marked starting with the healthy population, under 60 years of age. We have finished (vaccinating) people who have chronic diseases, the elderly and that is important. We are starting with the 59-year-old group of the population, tomorrow those who are 58 and the next day those who are 57 years old and so we will continue until they are 50 years old. We want to ensure that this entire age range between 50 and 59 years is vaccinated before April 9, "said the Undersecretary of Public Health, Paula Daza."    https://www.dw.com/es/chile-iniciar%C3%A1-la-vacunaci%C3%B3n-contra-la-covid-19-este-jueves-24-de-diciembre/a-56044566  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111201030/https://www.gob.cl/yomevacuno/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210208233218/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/presidente-pinera-da-inicio-a-la-vacunacion-masiva-contra-el-covid-19-en-todo-chile-es-un-tremendo-desafio-y-una-verdadera-epopeya/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210329174435/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/minsal-inicia-proceso-de-vacunacion-de-poblacion-sana/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301180410/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/pacientes-de-cancer-y-de-enfermedades-autoinmunes-podran-vacunarse-contra-el-covid-19-partir-de-este-lunes-1-de-marzo/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162249/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/partir-de-este-lunes-mas-de-89-mil-personas-con-discapacidad-severa-o-profunda-recibiran-primera-dosis-contra-el-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210322162512/https://www.gob.cl/noticias/chile-recibe-209-mil-dosis-adicionales-de-la-vacuna-pfizer-biontech-y-laboratorio-cansino-solicita-autorizacion-ante-el-isp/
notes_H3: The law ruling the Ministry of Health of Chile establishes that any unforeseen disease (such as COVID-19) should be tested to anybody who is suspect of having it. They released the report with such information on March 30. It is not clear the exact day they started testing.  https://www.minsal.cl/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/INFORME_EPI_COVID19_20200330.pdf  Official Contact Tracing Guidelines published (6 March 2020): https://www.minsal.cl/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/2020.03.06_PROTOCOLO-SEGUIMIENTO-CONTACTOS-CASOS-CONFIRMADOS_COVID-19.pdf
notes_C5: Transportation is running on a reduced schedule.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201113065927/https://www.gob.cl/coronavirus/plandeaccion/

name: China
notes_H1: The National Health Commission maintains a dedicated website on prevention and control of covid-19 covering daily official notifications on the situation, news, policy announcements, public health education and Q&As.  Similar contents are also pushed through its official wechat account on the social media in different formats including videos and infographics.  Earliest archived links on 25 Jan: https://web.archive.org/web/20200125111315/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/xxgzbd/gzbd_index.shtml ; https://web.archive.org/web/20200125131140/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/xxgzbd/gzbd_index.shtml ; https://web.archive.org/web/20200125171110/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/xcs/xxgzbd/gzbd_index.shtml ; https://web.archive.org/web/20200515072508/https://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MjM5NjI2ODA4Mw%3D%3D&amp=&mid=2653026291&amp=&idx=1&amp=&sn=30c83ca6019e9d72171b112ff37f4e02&amp=&chksm=bd3e86af8a490fb93b1b9d84fcb3981d4bed57f30e8b8e822eaef86f3552e178993e39db6028 ; https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://wemp.app/accounts/56c44cd4-9e6a-4aa1-aa0f-a1118c43d617?page=293

notes_C7: From 5 April 2021, three areas in Ruili, a county-level city in the west of Yunnan province, were marked as high-risk areas: train, long distance bus and taxi were all suspended. Six other areas in the same city became mid-risk areas.    https://archive.vn/7dSZp  https://archive.vn/mgl06
notes_C1: Schools in the urban area of Ruili, a county-level city in the west of Yunnan province, were shut down from 31 March 2021 as new local cases occurred.    https://archive.vn/yYiTf
notes_H6: The official data show that by 22 February there is no high/mid-risk area in the Mainland; in low-risk areas, residents are only required to wear masks in some public spaces.    https://archive.vn/39cZT
notes_E2: Loan relief policy: http://web.archive.org/web/20200924071933/http://www.gov.cn/zhengce/zhengceku/2020-02/01/content_5473639.htm  Guideline to prevent services such as electricity, gas and heating from stopping: http://web.archive.org/web/20201114104246/http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/gwylflkjz27/index.htm
notes_E1: As of April 11,  special measures have been introduced to facilitate access to unemployment insurance payments. These include relaxed application deadlines and certification requirements as well as new online application forms. (1.) However, benefits remain inaccessible to a large portion of the population without formal employment contracts or unemployment insurance policies. (2.)    (1.) https://web.archive.org/web/20200531120945/http://www.gov.cn/xinwen/2020-04/11/content_5501214.htm     (2.) https://p.dw.com/p/3aolH
notes_C3: From 5 April 2021, three areas in Ruili, a county-level city in the west of Yunnan province, were marked as high-risk areas. Public events were cancelled within the areas. Six other areas in the same city became mid-risk areas.    https://archive.vn/7dSZp  https://archive.vn/mgl06
notes_C6: From 5 April 2021, three areas in Ruili, a county-level city in the west of Yunnan province, were marked as high-risk areas, where residential communities are under total confinement. Six other areas in the same city became mid-risk areas.    https://archive.vn/7dSZp  https://archive.vn/mgl06
notes_H8: On 28 January, the National Health Commission issued the "Notice to Prevent and Control COVID-19 to Protect Elderly People." In particular, this notice includes a letter to all senior citizens, which recommends them staying at home as much as possible; avoiding going to crowded public places; if public transport is unavoidable, elderly people should wear masks at all times and washing hands once get back home etc. This letter has altogether 12 advice. Accessible through the following link (I have included the archived version and the unarchived URL so that once can download the attachments).    This notice also includes a guideline for elderly care institutions. Measures include stop accepting new residents, reduce visitors, visitors are limited to designated areas, if elderly residents have been to epidemic areas, the institution should persuade them to suspend the plan for coming back to institutions, or should pass the quarantine period in designated sections before returning to normal living areas. This attachment should be able to access through the unarchived version.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201214234528/http://www.nhc.gov.cn/lljks/tggg/202001/96e82ba8a14d41b283da990d39771493.shtml?
notes_C2: From 5 April 2021, three areas in Ruili, a county-level city in the west of Yunnan province, were marked as high-risk areas. Non-essential business within the areas were closed. Six other areas in the same city became mid-risk areas.    https://archive.vn/7dSZp  https://archive.vn/mgl06
notes_C4: From 5 April 2021, three areas in Ruili, a county-level city in the west of Yunnan province, were marked as high-risk areas, where residential communities are under total confinement. Six other areas in the same city became mid-risk areas.    https://archive.vn/7dSZp  https://archive.vn/mgl06
notes_H7: Vaccination policy differs across cities. For example, some cities/provinces, including Beijing and Wuhan, have started to vaccinated undergraduates since late March; in some cities/provinces, including Shanghai and Guangdong, foreign residents can make appointment for vaccination from early- and mid-April (in Guangdong, foreign residents not in the social welfare system need to pay 100RMB (c.15 USD) per jab). And in many cities, vaccines have started to roll-out to the over-60s.     https://archive.vn/DaSP3  https://archive.vn/yexnQ  https://archive.vn/3Iost  https://archive.vn/1C4q5  https://archive.vn/8VHvW    None of the news above specified which vaccine is being administered.
notes_H3: According to the notification of Wuhan health commission, serious contact tracing is being pursued.   163 close contacts have been traced and put under medical observation.  Source:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200514235719/http://wjw.wuhan.gov.cn/xwzx_28/gsgg/202004/t20200430_1199589.shtml

name: Cote d'Ivoire
notes_H1: http://info-covid19.gouv.ci/
notes_H2: On march 16, government announced that testing and care for suspected and confirmed cases of Covid-19 would be free:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200510115104/http://www.gouv.ci/doc/1584396935COMMUNIQUE-DU-CONSEIL-NATIONAL-DE-SECURITE-RELATIF-A-LA-SITUATION-DE-LA-PANDEMIE-DE-LA-MALADIE-A-CORONAVIRUS-2019-COVID-19-EN-COTE-D-IVOIRE.pdf
notes_C7: Domestic flights have resumed, no specific restrictions on domestic movement. https://web.archive.org/web/20200803232532/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-cote-divoire-extends-state-emergency-through-july-30-easing-lockdown-greater-abidjan
notes_C1: Per the US State Department, all schools, including universities, are open. https://web.archive.org/web/20201221152046/https://ci.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Face coverings are outside of the house.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210131195011/https://ci.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/manditory   https://web.archive.org/web/20210131201031/https://crisis24.garda.com/insights/news-alerts/wip10011879520/cote-divoire-authorities-reintroduce-covid-19-related-nationwide-state-of-health-emergency-jan-21-update-19
notes_E2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/ivory-coast-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html    On 21 March 2020, the CBWAS took major measures, in order to mitigate the negative impact of the sanitary crisis:  A FCFA340bn financial help has been granted to commercial banks, so they can sustain the economy;  1,700 companies have been granted loans, while they were not eligible so far, so that they can benefit from further resources;  The West African Development Bank (WADB) will receive FCFA25bn from the CBWAS, in order to lower its interest rate and increase the amount of loans granted to WAMU members, so as to be able to fund the domestic economy;  To accept to delay financial debt reimbursements, especially for SMEs;  To decrease the cost of fund transfers through mobile money, in order to avoid a low in transactions;  To fund commercial banks with enough cash to guarantee a good working of cash machines;  If necessary, to reorganize the schedule of Treasury bills issuance.  The government announced several measures to preserve the key sectors of the economy:  The setting up of a private sector support fund for an amount of XOF 250 billion, in order to strengthen the SMEs with at least XOF 100 billion and the setting up of guarantee funds, in order to facilitate the access to bank credits;  The setting up of a specific support fund for informal sector enterprises affected by the crisis for an amount of XOF100 billion.  Support for the main sectors of the national economy, particularly cashew nuts, cotton, rubber, oil palm, cocoa and coffee with  XOF 250 billion;  Support for food, market gardening and fruit production for an amount of CFAF 50 billion, including CFAF 20 billion for inputs.
notes_E1: I do not show any additional support beyond the initial donation above, however Unicef is working in partnerships with locals to provide other support for children and families in need but I dont see any formal information.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210110223002/https://www.unicef.org/stories/cote-divoire-protecting-children-and-young-people-move-during-covid-19
notes_C3: In researching the topic, there is nothing to indicate a cancellation of public events. In reviewing past comments, there are around mask measures. To whit, public events are allowed and NOT being discouraged.
notes_C6: A State of Emergency remains in effect, Social distancing and a reduction in non-essential movements are encouraged, though not enforced.  Vulnerable populations, including the elderly, pregnant women, and those with chronic health conditions, are advised to remain at home.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201230033209/https://ci.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: People can travel in via the airport but land and sea borders remain closed with the xecption of cargo shipping, whihc is still permitted. All air passengers mist be screened and show proof of a negative test. https://ci.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Cameroon
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health has a webpage dedicated to COVID 19 and the website is functional with fairly regular updates. It also includes different posters on the right way to combat the virus. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210214231959/https://covid19.minsante.cm/
notes_H2: The US Embassy in Cameroon confirms that there is testing available;  The following facilities provide COVID-19 testing in Cameroon: Centre Pasteur and National Public Health Laboratory in Yaounde, and the Laquintinie Hospital in Douala. The Cameroon government has announced that these tests are free of charge.  Once the patient submits their sample, results are sent to him/her by email, text message, or physical copy within 24 hours unless otherwise specified by the testing facility.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210125013417/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: There is no restriction to movement in place according to the Embassy of the US in Cameroon. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206224307/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Older students go back to school on 15 Oct with strict safety measures: masks, social distancing, frequent hand santiation, etc.     https://archive.vn/iZ55W
notes_H6: Wearing a mask in public became compulsory in Cameroon from 13 April.    https://archive.vn/V6RmP
notes_E2: No new information was found for this placeholder.
notes_E1: continued payment of family allowances was only from May to July to staff of companies which are unable to pay social security contributions or which have placed their staff on technical leave due to the crisis. No mention of continuing this policy in August. See: https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 (web archive not working, but previous notes have captured the same statement)
notes_C3: Religious gathering are not prohibited but there is a restriction on gatherings. It is limited to 50 people according to the UK government on travel to Cameroon. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206224531/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cameroon/coronavirus
notes_C8: The Embassy of the US in Cameroon confirms that there is screening for passengers. Although quarantine is not required, travellers are encouraged to limit contact with others for 14 days after their trip. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201206224307/https://cm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: There are social distancing measures in place but nothing in particular for the elderly. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308051826/https://twitter.com/DrManaouda/status/1366304088057655297
notes_C2: According to the UK Government's website on travel to Cameroon, visits to public institutions, including government buildings, have been limited. Please see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210117234822/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/cameroon/coronavirus

name: Democratic Republic of Congo
notes_H1: few news announcements related to covid - much is handled at the local level https://archive.vn/Z1HN0  "Public health measures can change at short notice and you should monitor local media for the latest developments."

notes_C1: schools have been open since August 3rd, 2020. "The resumption of schools and universities, starting with final classes and promotions" - this is the Official information site of the Ministry of Health for the DRC https://archive.vn/QaXY6
notes_H6: https://archive.vn/Z1HN0 Wearing face masks is mandatory in Kinshasa for anyone in public areas. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn. Wearing facemasks is mandatory in South Kivu.
notes_E2: Most of the relief measures ended in June (this information is also included in the last note for this indicator on May 6th 2020). For example, in April, the government granted, for 2 months, the supply of water and electricity free of charge to households, hospitals as well as micro & small and medium-sized enterprises which are affected by the closure measure as part of the response against COVID-19;  there was also a measure to prohibit the eviction of tenants who did not honour their commitments only from March to June 2020. No new relief measures have been evident since then. See: https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/drc-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html; Also, https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 [accessed 8th October 2020, web archive unavailable]

notes_C8: https://web.archive.org/web/20201222020649/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? No  Travelers entering the DRC, regardless of the origin of their travel, are not required to quarantine so long as they show a negative COVID-19 test taken within 7 days of departure from their point of origin and receive a negative COVID-19 test upon arrival.  Following the sample collection at the airport, travelers must self-quarantine until they receive a negative test result, generally within 24 hours.

notes_H2: Healthcare in the Republic of Congo  For contact details for English speaking doctors visit our list of healthcare providers.    If you think you have COVID-19 symptoms, you should call the response number: 3434      Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315201653/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus
notes_C7: Public places and services  Gatherings of more than 50 people are prohibited, with the exception of public markets, which are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs are closed.    Face masks must be worn in all public places.    The Republic of Congo authorities have mobilised defence and security forces to ensure compliance with the lockdown measures, at the entrance and exit of all cities across the country.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315201653/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/coronavirus
notes_C1: According to the UNESCO website, schools in the Democratic Republic of Congo are open.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308154708/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: From 30 April, the President of the Republic of Congo announced that the use of face masks would be compulsory in public spaces.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200911005454/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/338286/congo-government-extends-covid-19-lockdown-measures-until-may-15-update-4
notes_E2: The IMF states that the government has adopted some measures to ease tax and duty payments for private enterprises. In particular, more time has been given to companies to pay their taxes and tax assessments on site have been abandoned. The import duty directorate is also strongly encouraging electronic payment of dues and allowing more electronic documents to be accepted at the port. Corporate income tax has been reduced to 28 percent from 30 percent and the turnover tax has been reduced to 5 percent from 7 percent for small businesses with turnover below 100 million XAF, although these measures will apply in 2021.  Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210201005218/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: No current information on income support in Congo.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210315143057/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Due to the banning of public gatherings above 50 people (apart from public markets), public events are restricted by implication. However, due to no explicit mention that public events are banned, it is assumed that they are recommended not to be held (rather than required).   https://web.archive.org/web/20201021185847/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/-coronavirus
notes_C6: Public places and services  A curfew is in place from 18 December between 9pm and 5am. You should not be outside without justifiable reason (eg a medical emergency during these hours).    Wearing of facemasks is mandatory for anyone in public areas. This includes in public and private transport. The police will issue fines of 5000 Congolese Francs ($3) if masks are not worn.    DRC authorities have announced the following public health measures:    businesses, banks, restaurants and shops have re-opened in Kinshasa with social distancing measures in place.  places of worship, stadiums and performance halls have reopened with social distancing measures in place.  schools, colleges and universities are closed.  social enterprises eg bars and nightclubs remain closed  Public health measures can change at short notice and you should monitor local media for the latest developments.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308153330/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308160828/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: According to the US EMbassy in the Congo, all international passengers are required to self-quarantine for two weeks in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival. Passengers in transit will be quarantined at their expense at designated facilities until they resume their travels.    There are also health procedures at the point of entry. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129205003/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: Country-Specific Information:    There is a nationwide curfew in the DRC each evening from 9 pm to 5 am. Masks are required in public spaces.  Businesses, schools, airports, and ports are open.  While DRC permits borders open, many neighboring countries continue to restrict border crossings.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210405200921/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: According to the website of the US Embassy in  Congo, public markets are open on weekdays (except Wednesday) and Saturday.    Bars and nightclubs that were closed are now open.    Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129205003/https://cg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: Gatherings of more than 50 people as well as of family events such as weddings and funerals are prohibited. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/congo/staying-during-coronavirus

name: Colombia
notes_H1: There’s an ongoing coordinated public information campaign through traditional channels and social media at least since March 9 onwards. Here’s some examples: Ministry of Health’s campaign, posted on March 9: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JYaA-k2g4Hs  Other videos from the Ministry of Health available here: https://www.youtube.com/user/MinSaludColPrensa/videos  Ministry of Education’s campaign, posted on March 9: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NPGBNjxJcGE Other videos from the Ministry of Education available here:  https://www.youtube.com/user/mineducacion/videos  Plus these: http://web.archive.org/web/20200603125610/https://www.minsalud.gov.co/English/Paginas/historico-noticias.aspx
notes_H2: The first version of the guidelines on the detection of COVID cases that all health providers must follow were issued and approved by the Ministry of Health on January 31, 2020. Since this version of the guidelines, anyone who "fits" the symptoms of COVID must be tested by the health provider.  Here's the link to the first version of the guidelines: http://eselavega-cundinamarca.gov.co/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/GIPS05-LINEAMIENTOS-IPS.pdf   The revised version of the guidelines was issued on March 19 and it included more details about the description of the types of cases, but maintained the policy of testing anyone who is symptomatic. Here's the link to the second version of the guidelines:  https://www.minsalud.gov.co/Ministerio/Institucional/Procesos%20y%20procedimientos/GIPS05.pdf
notes_C7: A 4-day strict quarantine is in effect since Thursday in the capital city of Bogota, which is now on "Red Alert".  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110055917/https://gestion.pe/mundo/capital-de-colombia-decreta-cuarentena-por-segunda-ola-de-covid-19-temen-presencia-de-nueva-cepa-noticia/
notes_C1: In Colombia, some schools have been opened with reduced and limited capacity (with 20-30% of the total capacity) and with an alternation model, in which in the same year, some students go to school and others see the class from home. In addition, the use of face masks, disinfection or frequent hand washing and temperature measurement upon admission is mandatory. However, the return to face-to-face classes was only for private schools, since the vast majority of public schools in the country continue with virtual classes.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201205234325/https://www.infobae.com/america/colombia/2020/10/15/esta-listo-el-piloto-de-regreso-a-clases-en-19-colegios-de-bogota/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205234152/https://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/barranquilla/regreso-a-clases-clases-presenciales-en-colegios-de-barranquilla-551074  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205234152/https://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/barranquilla/regreso-a-clases-clases-presenciales-en-colegios-de-barranquilla-551074  https://web.archive.org/web/20201205235220/https://chequeado.com/el-explicador/como-es-la-vuelta-a-las-clases-presenciales-en-america-latina/
notes_H6: The use of masks is mandatory when using public transport and in public spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201104050936/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/colombia/coronavirus
notes_E2: After the issuance of Decree 417, on March 17 2020,  the citizens that have to pay rent cannot be evicted from their homes during the emergency and up to two months after it. In addition, during the economic emergency, and for two months more, the leasing fees cannot be increased.
