notes_H3: 'In response to the first case of new coronavirus infection in Australia, the SAR government has launched and deployed anti-epidemic work in an all-round way, taking necessary measures including implementing heat detection at ports and filling in entry declaration forms to fully respond to, prevent and control the epidemic.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200403075243/https://news.gov.mo/detail/zh-hant/N20AV4AiJe;jsessionid=AE280AF2AFB28803D49190392A304F09.app03?0

name: Morocco
notes_H1: The telephone platform of listening and guidance "Allo 300", set up since March 25, 2020 to provide citizens with advice and information on the new coronavirus (Covid-19), has so far recorded about 38,000 phone calls, for an average of 9,500 calls per day, a military source said on Monday.    Retrieved from: https://web.archive.org/web/20200409102532/http://www.maroc.ma/en/news/covid-19-allo-300-platform-records-nearly-38k-calls-average-9500-calls-day
notes_H2: If you are exhibiting signs or symptoms of COVID-19, please contact the Moroccan Ministry of Health’s hotline at +212 (0)8-0100-4747. Assistance is available in English, French or Arabic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121090354/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/
notes_C7: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Regional or local authorities may put into place (sometimes with little notice) travel or other restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  Individuals entering or departing from the Casablanca city limits must have a letter of permission issued by Moroccan authorities. In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.    Is a curfew in place? There is a curfew in Casablanca between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Yes    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Schools are fully open with precautionary measures in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201121082517/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: The use of masks is mandatory.  Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019012009/https://ma.usembassy.gov/25161/  Also see:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201019005808/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/morocco/coronavirus
notes_E2: On October 5, the government launched a new facility to provide financing to real estate firms (Damane Relance Promotion Immobilière). On January 6, 2021 the government extended the Damane Relance facility until end-March 2021.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210301111203/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: On March 23, it was announced that: Employees affiliated with the social security system will benefit from a 2000 dirhams monthly allocation (approximately 202 USD). They will also benefit from a suspension of loans and consumption credits reimbursements, until 30 June 2020. With high levels of informality, the Economic Watch Committee decided on 23 March to provide financial relief to informal workers suffering from the economic impact COVID-19.   Workers in the informal sector, starting with households benefiting from the medical assistance  plan RAMED and which no longer have an income due to compulsory confinement, will receive  800 DH per month for households of two people or less; 1,000 DH per month for households  of three to four people; 1,200 DH per month for households of more than four people.  Households without RAMED operating in the informal sector and who have lost their income following compulsory confinement will also benefit from this provision by filling out their requests in an electronic platform dedicated to this purpose.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507103621/https://www.oecd.org/mena/competitiveness/The-Covid-19-Crisis-in-Morocco.pdf
notes_C3: Morocco's Interior Ministry announced cancellation of all sporting, cultural, and artistic events in the country, until further notice from 14 March https://web.archive.org/web/20200601135438/https://www.moroccoworldnews.com/2020/03/296129/morocco-bans-public-gatherings-of-over-50-people-cancels-all-events/
notes_C6: A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am. . In Casablanca, there is an evening curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am.  Those who circulate within Casablanca during these hours must have proper authorization from local authorities.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Government reopens borders to 67 visa-exempt countries with some restrictions. Citizens of those countries cleared to travel to Morocco without a visa will be allowed entry, provided that they have an express invitation from a Morocco company or a confirmed hotel reservation.(MSN News, 14.09.2020).    All travellers planning to fly to Morocco must have valid negative Covid-19 test results issued no more than 48 hours before their flight.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200925052707/https://travelbans.org/africa/morocco/
notes_H8: All age groups are required to stay at home in cities and districts that are under curfew. Now the curfew is nationwide. A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am. Thus, that requires elderly people to stay at home as well in these hours by default.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: On December 21, the Government of Morocco announced additional restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  The measures will take effect on Wednesday, December 23 and will remain in place for three weeks. The new measures include the following:  A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am;  A daily closing time for restaurants, cafes, shops, and supermarkets of 8:00 pm;  The closure of all restaurants and cafes in Agadir, Casablanca, Marrakech, and Tangier; and  A ban on all public and private gatherings and parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: On December 21, the Government of Morocco announced additional restrictions aimed at stopping the spread of COVID-19.  The measures will take effect on Wednesday, December 23 and will remain in place for three weeks. The new measures include the following:  A nationwide curfew between the hours of 9:00 pm and 6:00 am;  A daily closing time for restaurants, cafes, shops, and supermarkets of 8:00 pm;  The closure of all restaurants and cafes in Agadir, Casablanca, Marrakech, and Tangier; and  A ban on all public and private gatherings and parties.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210101012734/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: A,B,C: Sinopharm and AstraZeneca  Which vaccines are available in Morocco? Sinopharm (China) and AstraZeneca (UK)  For information on getting vaccinated in Morocco, please contact the COVID-19 Vaccination Hotline, “Allo Liqah,”at 08-00-00-01-47 (French and Arabic) or visit their website at https://liqahcorona.ma/fr.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210402235135/https://ma.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    The COVID-19 virus vaccination campaign targets citizens over the age of 17, according to a two-shot vaccination schedule. This target population is estimated at 25,000,000. Priority will be given to certain targets, in particular front-line personnel, in this case, health professionals, public authorities, security forces and education personnel. national level, as well as to the elderly and those vulnerable to the virus, before extending it to the rest of the population.    https://liqahcorona.ma/fr/page-je-minforme-sur-le-vaccin#209 (this website is not being archived)
notes_H3: The Ministry of Health ('the Ministry') announced, on 1 June 2020, that it is launching the 'WIQAYTNA' tracing app for contact tracing during the COVID-19 ('Coronavirus') crisis. In particular, the Ministry noted that the app will be based on bluetooth technology and will notify users in case they come into prolonged contact with an individual who has tested positive for Coronavirus. In addition, the Ministry is collaborating closely with the Digital Development Agency and the National Telecommunications Regulatory Authority ('ANRT'), and highlighted that the app has been approved by the Moroccan data protection authority ('CNDP').
notes_C5: 23 October: Tighter curbs announced for Greater Casablanca, which includes the Casablanca and Mohammadia prefectures and Naouceur and Mediouna provinces, as well as the Berrechid and Benslimane provinces. Measures include the prohibition of all forms of night movement between 9pm and 6am; the closing of community grounds and parks; closing restaurants, cafes, stores and large shopping centres at 8pm; the shutdown of public transportation buses and tramways at 9pm; closing local markets at 3pm; and promoting teleworking when possible.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201029142017/https://www.meed.com/tunisia-pushes-finance-bill-to-cope-with-covid-19

name: Monaco
notes_H1: From 9 am tomorrow, Friday 6 March, the COVID-19 Call Centre, a telephone information service, will take over, staffed by a dedicated team from the Department of Health Affairs (DASA), first aiders from the Monaco Red Cross and a medical supervisor.    Monegasque nationals, residents and employees can contact the centre to discuss any questions they may have about COVID-19 by calling 92 05 55 00. The line will be open every day from 9 am to 6 pm. The centre can also be emailed at the following address: covid19@gouv.mc .    The Prince’s Government would like to remind readers that in the event of any doubt, particularly if you have visited an area where the virus is circulating and have significant symptoms consistent with the disease (fever, cough, breathing difficulties, etc.) you should contact the emergency services directly on 18 or 112.    To avoid infecting others, people with symptoms are asked not to visit their normal doctor.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201203123750/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/CORONAVIRUS-Prince-s-Government-to-expand-COVID-19-telephone-information-service
notes_H2: PCR test is available to anyone: "If I am not in one of these 4 cases, but still want to do a PCR test, I can go to a laboratory in town. My test will be reimbursed with or without a prescription". Also, "It is recommended to do an antigen test in the following cases: If you want to be tested, without being identified as a high or low risk contact case, If you have had symptoms for less than 4 days."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115163618/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/tout-sur-les-tests-diagnostics/
notes_C7: Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, but no restrictions on internal movement otherwise.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409141322/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/sorties/
notes_C1: " Alesi    On 7 September 2020, Minister of State H.E. Mr Pierre Dartout visited Lycée Albert I upon the return of Year 13 (Terminale) pupils, who will sit the newly reformed General Baccalaureate examinations next June.    H.E. the Minister of State was accompanied by Mr Patrice Cellario, Minister of the Interior, and Ms Isabelle Bonnal, Director of Education, Youth and Sport.    During the early afternoon, H.E. the Minister of State, Mgr David, Archbishop of Monaco, Mr Patrice Cellario and Ms Isabelle Bonnal were also keen to meet students and staff at the François d’Assise-Nicolas Barré primary school.    After witnessing the return of the five-year-old (Grande Section) nursery pupils, H.E. the Minister of State chatted to Year 2 (CP) and Year 5 (CM1) pupils and teaching staff.    During his discussions at the Principality’s schools, H.E. the Minister of State asked pupils how they felt about returning to school this year. They told him that they were happy to be able to get back to their lessons and to be with their friends again.    In the course of his visits, H.E. the Minister of State also welcomed the rigorous compliance with health guidelines on the part of all pupils and staff.    This September marks the beginning of a new school year for the 518 teachers and 5,774 pupils enrolled in Monaco’s schools."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201226070954/https://en.gouv.mc/Policy-Practice/Coronavirus-Covid-2019/Actualites/2020-2021-school-year-begins
notes_H6: Masks must be worn in all public spaces, and in all closed spaces open to the public and shared areas of private spaces.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210126122206/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_E2: No measures in place.
notes_E1: Employees who have been laid off and who usually receive a gross base salary of less than or equal to EUR 2,075.16 for 169 hours per month are entitled to their full net salary. Employees earning a gross base salary of between EUR 2,075.17 and EUR 2,571.43, for 169 hours per month, will be entitled to the safeguard clause at a rate of EUR 1,800.00. In the case of higher salaries, a cap has been set at 4.5 times the minimum wage.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409144615/https://covid19.mc/en/thematiques/travail/
notes_C3: Public gatherings are limited to six people, but places of worship are allowed to remain open with a limit of 1 person per 6 square meters.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C6: Curfew in place from 8pm to 6am, with exceptions for work, health and family reasons.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C8: Travelers are required to quarantine unless they are able to show proof of a negative PCR test taken at most 72 hours prior to arrival. In the event of a positive PCR, or if the person refuses to be tested, the quarantine will be maintained.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409142722/https://covid19.mc/en/i-come-from-abroad/
notes_H8: No policy updates. Measures introduced on November 1st 2020 will remain in place until March 19 at least.   A curfew remains in place (7pm-6am).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210316061327/https://covid19.mc/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/
notes_C2: Working from home is compulsory in the private and public sector until the 18th of April, but public services, hotels, banks, businesses, and public establishments remain open with restrictions in place. Employees are required to go to work if their employer does not wish to conduct work remotely.    "Teleworking is compulsory as soon as it is practicable. For the private sector, work must be conducted remotely when the nature of the employee's activity is compatible with his remote exercise and the employer can make the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise available to him. For the public sector, remote work must be used for the entire weekly working time of the civil servant or agent of the State, with his agreement, provided that the nature of his activity is compatible with its exercise remotely and that it has the technical and material resources necessary for such an exercise."    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210409135212/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210409143359/https://covid19.mc/en/working-from-home/
notes_C4: Due to the worldwide COVID-19 epidemic, Monaco has imposed severe restrictions on public life: A curfew has been in effect since Tuesday (17 March). People are only allowed to leave their homes for justified purposes, while restaurants, museums, and non-essential shops are closed throughout the country. Persons entering the country from risk areas must undergo a 14-day domestic quarantine.     http://web.archive.org/web/20201216070845/https://global-monitoring.com/gm/page/events/epidemic-0002086.Eg778z0AGwE9.html?lang=en
notes_H7: B, C:  People who are aged 65 years or older as well as those over 18 years old with chronic conditions are eligible for vaccination. Note: It was not clear when new groups were added for COVID vaccination.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210208001703/https://vaccination-covid19.gouv.mc/comment-prendre-rendez-vous
notes_H3: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126123014/https://covid19.mc/en/mesures/jai-ete-en-contact-avec-une-personne-positive-a-la-covid-19-que-faire/
notes_C5: The Monegasque Bus Company (CAM) is resuming normal service for all buses, including the Bateau Bus (water bus). The only exceptions to this are the night services, N1 and N2, which will remain closed.     The following health measures apply:    The wearing of masks is mandatory on public transport  Tickets can be purchased on board, on condition that you pay the exact amount  Tickets are also available from the 12 automatic ticket machines located throughout the Principality, and the shop at 22/24 Rue du Gabian is open from 8.30 am to 4.30 pm Monday to Friday  The following procedures continue to apply:    Buses will be disinfected twice a day  Dispensers of hydro-alcoholic gel have been installed in every bus  Buses will stop at every stop (to avoid the need for people to press the buttons)  Passenger information showing the direction in which you should walk when boarding, leaving and while on the bus, is displayed on the floor and doors of the bus  It is forbidden to get off the bus  at the front    https://web.archive.org/web/20210115150310/https://covid19.mc/en/les-mesures-sanitaires-a-compter-du-1er-novembre-2020/

name: Moldova
notes_H1: Public Information campaign appears organised with posters giving specific advice and instructions. https://web.archive.org/web/20200727231717/https://msmps.gov.md/minister/comunicare/covid-19/
notes_H2: Suspected cases are tested in order to classify and report them based on standard procedures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200517130545/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/moldova/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.5%20Testing&Type=Section
notes_C7: Depending on the zone, individuals are in, it is recommended not to travel inside the country.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201008021259/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UN%20Moldova%20COVID-19%20Response%20and%20Recovery%20Monlty%20Bulletin%20-%20September%202020.pdf
notes_C1: Almost all districts in the country are under the Red Code. Therefore a state of public health emergency was declared throughout the Republic of Moldova from March 19 to April 18, 2021, inclusive. Education in the country will be organized according to the epidemiological indicators in the locality. It will remain at the discretion of local authorities, educational institutions, and early education institutions to stop the educational process, including for primary classes, or continue their studies:  - Green or Yellow Code: pre-school children, pupils and students can go to school  - Orange Code: pre-school children, pupils of the elementary school, pupils from the graduate forms (9th, 12th, 13th of the evening school), pupils from vocational schools involved in the probations and in graduate groups, and students from graduate years of the higher education in practical classes can go to school; pupils and students from other forms and education years are on distance education.   - Red Code: distance education is recommended. Depending on the epidemiological situation at the institution, the education process can be organized as follows: (i) Daily participation of the pre-school children and elementary school pupils in the education institutions with physical presence. (ii) Daily participation with physical presence in the education institutions of a contingent of 50 per cent of all the number of pupils of the graduate forms (9th, 12th, 13th of the evening school), as well as of the pupils from the vocational education involved in probations and in the graduate groups and of the students from graduate years from the higher education, with the strict observance of the public health norms as to the prevention and spread of COVID-19.   (iii) Daily participation of the pupils and students from other forms and education years in the distance education.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210322194909/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/20/21002116  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322191211/https://gov.md/ro/content/aureliu-ciocoi-dupa-sedinta-cnesp-venit-timpul-ca-fiecare-ramura-puterii-din-republica
notes_H6: The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Face-masks are mandatory in all public spaces, including outdoors.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: Banks are allowed to instigate payment holidays until June 30. Income tax payments have been suspended. https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html;https://www.ebrd.com/where-we-are/moldova/overview.html
notes_E1: "The government will also assist businesses that have suspended their activities (fully or partially) by refunding personal income taxes and social security contributions up to 100%. Those that had to stop their operations due to decision of authorities will receive a subsidy amounting to 100% of their income tax, social security and health contributions, and other compulsory state payments. Persons who have worked for at least nine months at one enterprise and have lost their jobs will be paid from 60 to 80% of their final salary. Banks were also incentivised to delay payment deadlines and/or the amounts of due payments on loans until 30 June."https://www.oecd.org/coronavirus/policy-responses/covid-19-crisis-response-in-eu-eastern-partner-countries/
notes_C3: Due to an increase in the epidemiologic situation, restrictions are in place 01 March through 15 March, inclusively.  This includes:  Thus, the education will be held online in the primary education institutions, gymnasiums, lyceums, extra-school institutions and vocational schools and higher schools, private and public institutions. The school Olympiads will no longer be able to be held with the physical presence of people.      At the same time, the presence of spectators in the work of the theatre and concert institutions, as well as community centres is banned and the public transport will be ceased on Saturday and Sunday in the Chisinau city. The Chisinau municipality’s national extraordinary public health commission will establish a limited regime of movement of the public transport in the area of the Chisinau city.     The public institutions and the private ones will ensure a special working regime, through attracting of the strictly needed staff to work and the distance work will be instructed for the other employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020043/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-establishes-special-activity-regime  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013930/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/social  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013505/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: On 05 March, commercial centers were allowed to re-open on weekends.  In addition, the decision was made to increase restrictions in “red” districts:    In the eastern districts, where the red code of alert is established, measures of preventing the infection with Covid-19 infection will be implemented, such as:    1. restricting residents’ movement and isolation at home;    2. banning the mass meetings, including of the kind of cultural, scientific, artistic, sports or entertainment activities with people’s physical participation;  3. providing of only the essential (vital) services;    4. prohibition of non-essential visits to public interests units (bank, post office, etc.) ;  5. adjusted and only essential medical assistance services;  6. establishment of the online education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214933/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-commercial-centres-resume-working-saturdays-sundays  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220013/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/postanovlenie_no_49_ot_5_marta_2021_g._nacionalnoy_chrezvychaynoy_komissii_obshchestvennogo_zdorovya.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314221448/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/05/21001722  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220811/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214534/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Effective March 5, 2021, anyone entering Moldova must present a negative COVID-19 test taken within the previous 72 hours or they will be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210322184956/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: From 25 March, Moldova began implementing protections for persons over 63 years of age in Decision 3 of the National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP):    1. It is prohibited for persons over 63 years of age, starting on the 25th March 2020, being outside the home and in public spaces without with the exception of: (i) travel in the interests of the service, where the activity cannot be carried out at a distance, (ii) travel to ensure the food; (iii) travel for health care, which cannot be amenitated; (iv) travel for other justified and non-ecanable reasons (e.g. travel for other justified and non-ecant reasons) the death of a family member, the needs of persons and animals of company, etc.).    https://web.archive.org/web/20201213224424/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/dispozitia_3_din_23.03.2020_a_cse_a_rm.pdf
notes_C2: On 05 March, commercial centers were allowed to re-open on weekends.  In addition, the decision was made to increase restrictions in “red” districts:    In the eastern districts, where the red code of alert is established, measures of preventing the infection with Covid-19 infection will be implemented, such as:    1. restricting residents’ movement and isolation at home;    2. banning the mass meetings, including of the kind of cultural, scientific, artistic, sports or entertainment activities with people’s physical participation;  3. providing of only the essential (vital) services;    4. prohibition of non-essential visits to public interests units (bank, post office, etc.) ;  5. adjusted and only essential medical assistance services;  6. establishment of the online education.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214933/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-commercial-centres-resume-working-saturdays-sundays  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220013/https://gov.md/sites/default/files/postanovlenie_no_49_ot_5_marta_2021_g._nacionalnoy_chrezvychaynoy_komissii_obshchestvennogo_zdorovya.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314221448/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/05/21001722  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314220811/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210314214534/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C4: The National Extraordinary Public Health Commission (CNESP) has ruled to establish emergency state in the public health sector all over Moldova on the period 30 November 2020 – 15 January 2021:  Groups of more than three people are prohibited in public areas. Public parks are open, but people should not congregate in groups larger than three.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201205215306/https://gov.md/en/content/national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-declares-state-emergency-public-health-all   https://web.archive.org/web/20201205214717/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: A:  AstraZeneca    On 02 March, the first person was vaccinated with the AstraZeneca vaccine, donated by Romania to Moldova. According to the Ministry of Health, Labor and Social Protection, the first will be vaccinated doctors from intensive care and COVID departments. Subsequently, all employees in the medical system will benefit from the vaccine.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308021525/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/2021/03/02/21001591
notes_H3: Current restrictions from 30 November remain in place until 15 January.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210110000414/https://gov.md/en/comunicate-presa  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109235654/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: Due to an increase in the epidemiologic situation, restrictions are in place 01 March through 15 March, inclusively.  This includes:  Thus, the education will be held online in the primary education institutions, gymnasiums, lyceums, extra-school institutions and vocational schools and higher schools, private and public institutions. The school Olympiads will no longer be able to be held with the physical presence of people.      At the same time, the presence of spectators in the work of the theatre and concert institutions, as well as community centres is banned and the public transport will be ceased on Saturday and Sunday in the Chisinau city. The Chisinau municipality’s national extraordinary public health commission will establish a limited regime of movement of the public transport in the area of the Chisinau city.     The public institutions and the private ones will ensure a special working regime, through attracting of the strictly needed staff to work and the distance work will be instructed for the other employees.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020043/https://gov.md/en/content/moldovas-national-extraordinary-public-health-commission-establishes-special-activity-regime  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013930/https://www.moldpres.md/en/news/social  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308013505/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

name: Madagascar
notes_H1: No policy change
notes_H2: COVID-19 Testing  •	Are PCR and/or antigen tests available for U.S. citizens in Madagascar? Yes  •	If so, are test results reliably available within 72 hours? Yes  •	Polyclinique Ilafy and Hospital ManarapenitraAndenatepenaka offer PCR tests for COVID-19.  •	InstitutPasteur offers serological tests for COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405080216/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: Movement Restrictions:  •	Is a curfew in place? No  •	Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? Travel in or out of Nosy Be and Mahajanga is forbidden.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210405080216/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Previous coding: 0  New coding: 1G    Hygiene protocols are in place, even though there are reports that these are difficult for students to adhere to because e.g. handwashing with soap and water is a challenge.    https://archive.vn/nOfdw    Previous coding comment and sources:    On September 6, the president announced students can return to school on October 26th. "Pupils and students set on their return to class. According to the President of the Republic of the Republic, the start of the school year for the 2020-2021 school year is scheduled for October 26 for primary and secondary students in public institutions"     https://web.archive.org/web/20201125031144/https://2424.mg/education-la-rentree-scolaire-2020-2021-fixee-au-26-octobre-2020-sauf-pour-les-classes-terminales-la-rentree-universitaire-2019-2020-fixee-au-2-novembre-2020/     UNESCO's visualization of school closures also shows schools moving to Fully Open on October 26. https://web.archive.org/web/20201125031524/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: It is mandatory to wear a face mask in all public places, including in shops, parks and streets.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405080014/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_E2: Private sector supported through tax relief and suspension of government fees, but no similar policy applied to households.    See IMF's Policy Response Tracker (https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#M).
notes_E1: The Government of Madagascar has launched a social protection programme to assist families impacted by the Covid-19 outbreak through the use of unconditional cash transfers in urban and suburban areas. The beneficiaries of TOSIKA FAMENO, identified at the fokontany level and registered in the list of beneficiaries established by the respective municipalities, are very poor and vulnerable families, those most exposed to a risk of food insecurity as well as *those whose income is interrupted because of the lock down.*The amount of the transfer amounts to 100,000 Ariary per household, payable in a single installment , for the month of May 2020. A second transfer of the same amount (100,000 ariary) is planned. While only applying to very poor households, this measure still is a measure of income support that is independent of whether previous employment was in the formal or informal sector. As the level of income replacement is a flat rate well below 50 percent of median income, this is rated as 1A despite its limited reach. https://web.archive.org/web/20200505013014/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/africa-press-office/2020/04/28/coronavirus-in-madagascar-a-social-protection-response-is-launched-in-urban-and-suburban-areas-to-aid-families-and-their-children-during-covid-19-pandemic/; https://web.archive.org/web/20200531203933/https://www.fid.mg/tosika-fameno/#1590388088109-e657a849-66fd (see technical sheet for details)
notes_C3: Gatherings of more than 200 people are not permitted.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210405080014/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/madagascar/coronavirus
notes_C6: The State of Emergency was lifted October 18th with no further restrictions/advisement on staying at home, apart from  mask-wearing (covered by other criteria)    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232310/http://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/decret/997-decret-n-2020-1270-du-03-octobre-2020-prolongeant-la-duree-de-l-etat-d-urgence-sanitaire-sur-tout-le-territoire-de-la-republique.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232333/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232330/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232339/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/390636/madagascar-authorities-announce-end-of-state-of-health-emergency-october-18-update-19
notes_C8: All Foreign visitation is restricted to the island of Nosy Be, foreign citizens are not permitted elsewhere in Madagascar    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232310/http://www.presidence.gov.mg/actualites/decret/997-decret-n-2020-1270-du-03-octobre-2020-prolongeant-la-duree-de-l-etat-d-urgence-sanitaire-sur-tout-le-territoire-de-la-republique.html    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232333/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232330/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201128232339/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/390636/madagascar-authorities-announce-end-of-state-of-health-emergency-october-18-update-19
notes_H8: Local curfews eased.  "Curfews introduced in multiple areas of Madagascar to control the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) were lifted on Monday, October 5, following a fall in the rate of new infections in recent weeks. Curfew restrictions had initially been introduced nationwide under the country's state of health emergency in March before being partially eased in June, with the 22:00 to 04:00 curfew remaining in place in designated virus hotspots. The lifting of the curfew means that targeted restrictions have been eased in areas with higher COVID-19 transmission rates, including the Analamanga, Alaotra Mangoro, Diana, Sava, and Vakinankaratra regions.    Authorities have also announced the easing of public gathering restrictions from Monday, permitting groups of up to 200 to gather for religious, cultural, and sporting events. Schools, entertainment venues, and sports facilities have also been authorized to resume normal operations with appropriate hygiene and distancing measures in place. However, the use of face masks remains compulsory in public places."    http://web.archive.org/web/20210301124624/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/386456/madagascar-covid-19-curfew-lifted-as-state-of-health-emergency-extended-until-october-18-update-18
notes_C2: The State of Emergency ended on October 18, and there has been no guidance limiting workplaces since then.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125041932/https://mg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201125042022/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C4: Curfews that were previously introduced in multiple areas of Madagascar were lifted. Authorities have also announced the easing of public gathering restrictions from Monday, permitting groups of up to 200 to gather for religious, cultural, and sporting events.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201012213846/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    https://web.archive.org/web/20201012214310/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/386456/madagascar-covid-19-curfew-lifted-as-state-of-health-emergency-extended-until-october-18-update-18
notes_H3: In place with volunteers due to past plague outbreaks https://web.archive.org/web/20210405085741/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/how-contact-tracers-could-help-control-covid-19
notes_C5: "Public transportation will resume services from Wednesday, August 26."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200830181552/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/371926/madagascar-authorities-ease-measures-and-extend-national-state-of-health-emergency-through-september-7-update-16

name: Mexico
notes_H1: #QuedateEnCasa: https://web.archive.org/web/20201112133725/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/ Since 24th March: https://web.archive.org/web/20200920220127/https://mexico.as.com/mexico/2020/03/25/actualidad/1585105801_984693.html
notes_H2: The epidemiological surveillance of COVID-19 will change model from the instrumentation of the new operational definition, so that it is sentinel in the 475 units currently active for SISVEFLU (which will change its name to Epidemiological Surveillance System of Viral Respiratory Disease, SISVER) and where not only will COVID-19 be monitored, but also influenza and other respiratory viruses.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200414061918/https://www.gob.mx/cms/uploads/attachment/file/545445/AE_Enfermedad_COVID-19_SARS-CoV-2_2020.04.06.pdf
notes_C7: Restrictions on internal movement to be upheld according to "traffic light system" per state   /web/20200611070223/https://www.milenio.com/politica/coronavirus-mexico-10-junio-noticias-covid-19
notes_C1: Between 15 Feb and 28 Feb there are 2 regions under Red alert, 21 under Orange alert, 8 under Yellow alert and 1 under Green alert. School activities are allowed under Green alert only.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217220733/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_H6: " Several states and municipalities have imposed curfews and movement restrictions on non-essential activities and have required citizens to wear masks when outside the home."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312165454/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: 3 month loan extensions are available:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223132720/https://www.gob.mx/covid19medidaseconomicas/acciones-y-programas/creditos-infonavit
notes_E1: Government-provided low-interest loans are available:  Credits to support family micro-businesses and self-employed workers in the face of the effects caused by COVID-19  Financing of 25 thousand pesos per business or person, to be paid in three years, including three months of grace.  In other words, the beneficiaries will pay 824 pesos in 33 installments.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223132600/https://www.gob.mx/covid19medidaseconomicas/acciones-y-programas/apoyos-financieros-a-microempresas-y-trabajadores-independientes
notes_C3: In areas that are deemed "orange," cultural events are permitted but limited to 25% capacity, and orange is the strictest level currently being given to areas.     https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_C6: "Is a curfew in place? [Yes]  Curfews are not universal.  Restrictions vary based on state and/or city.  Please see the “Local Resources” section for curfew-specific information below."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312165454/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: "The Mexican government encourages people to continue respecting social distancing measures, washing their hands, and coughing or sneezing in the inner part of the elbow to prevent the spread of COVID-19.  A variety of prevention measures can be found at https://coronavirus.gob.mx  For U.S. citizens who have participated in higher risk activities or think that they may have been exposed before or during a trip, the CDC encourages people to take the following extra precautions to protect others for 14 days after arrival:  Stay home as much as possible.  Avoid staying around people at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19.  Consider getting tested for COVID-19.  In the United States, quarantine requirements and recommendations may vary by state.  Therefore, travelers should review an individual state’s entry requirements before traveling."      http://web.archive.org/web/20200927195013/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: On March 15, the National Government gave a list of 13 recommendations for elderly people. Recommendations involved keeping social distancing, avoiding physical contact, washing hand frequently, trusting official sources, etc. Interestingly, one recommendation was to avoid facial covering if there are no symptoms of the disease. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201213224027/https://www.infobae.com/america/mexico/2020/03/16/estas-son-las-medidas-de-prevencion-para-cuidar-a-los-adultos-mayores-y-evitar-contagios-de-coronavirus/
notes_C2: highest alert level is Orange which has these restrictions:  In addition to essential economic activities, companies of non-essential economic activities will be allowed to work with 30% of the personnel for their operation, always taking into account the maximum care measures for people with a greater risk of presenting a serious picture of COVID-19, open public spaces will be opened with a reduced capacity (number of people).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226000705/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/
notes_C4: No specific restrictions on gatherings in levels green, yellow, or orange. There are capacity restrictions on public spaces within levels yellow and orange.     https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/semaforo/  https://web.archive.org/web/*/https://mx.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: A,C:  Mexico has approved emergency use of the AstraZeneca, CanSino, Pfizer, SinoVac, and Sputnik V vaccines  The vaccine will be offered on a universal basis for free. Mexico will prioritize recipients by at-risk groups and age.   Phase 1: January-February 2021 – health care workers;  Phase 2: February-April 2021 – people 60 years old and older;    Phase 2 has begun in some regions  https://archive.vn/6kDtz  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219223344/https://coronavirus.gob.mx/vacunacion-covid/
notes_H3: According to the report, 555 persons were contacted. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210118023002/https://covid19.cdmx.gob.mx/storage/app/media/Reportes%20CSP/CS_4_ENERO_compressed.pdf
notes_C5: Is public transportation operating? [Yes]  Some states and municipalities have implemented additional transportation restrictions  https://archive.vn/6kDtz

name: Mali
notes_H1: In addition, social, sporting, cultural and political groupings of more than 50 people such as weddings, baptisms, funerals were banned.  Public, private and denominational schools, including madarsas will be closed for three weeks  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408211603/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/mali-suspends-flights-from-covid-19-hit-countries-/1769908
notes_H2: Tests are available if symptomatic, or to travellers at local facilities in Bamako (tests must be paid by travellers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308234507/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: THere is no information on internal movement after the curfew being lifted.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.worldaware.com/covid-19-alert-mali-lifts-nationwide-curfew-may-10
notes_C1: Schools reopening on 26/01/2021. Restrictions such as masks and social distancing apply.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210321190255/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/435086/mali-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-remain-mostly-unchanged-as-of-jan-26-update-8 *** https://web.archive.org/web/20210321190237/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse
notes_H6: As of 9th May 2020, Mali's government made mask wearing compulsory in public places.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200903122847/http://north-africa.com/2020/05/mali-ends-curfew-orders-mandatory-wearing-of-facemasks/
notes_E2: The three-month exemption (starting from May) would have expired in August and there is no indication that this was renewed. See https://web.archive.org/web/20201109002858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: It does not seem like the measures were extended up until now. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20201109002858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Correct link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210321190255/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/435086/mali-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-remain-mostly-unchanged-as-of-jan-26-update-8
notes_C6: "Is a curfew in place? No". However, general restrictions apply.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210308234507/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: The Government of Mali has implemented enhanced screening and quarantine measures to reduce the spread of COVID-19.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to go into effect with little or no advanced notice.  Incoming air travellers are required to:  •	Wear a mask.  •	Complete a form with contact information, travel history and health symptoms.   •	Present a negative COVID-19 test dated no more than seven days prior to arrival in Mali.  •	Any passenger who arrives without a negative COVID-19 test result or with a COVID-19 test result dated more than seven days before arrival will have their travel documents retained by airport officials and will be subjected to testing. Travelers must self-quarantine at home or at a hotel at their expense until the test result is available.  Anyone suspected of having COVID-19, despite presenting a negative COVID-19 test result, will be subject to testing.  If test results are positive, that person’s travel documents will be retained, and the traveler will be put into isolation at a government of Mali facility.  The travel documents will be returned once the patient is deemed free of COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: Lockdown ended on 28/12  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.africanews.com/2020/12/19/mali-goes-into-lockdown-to-fight-the-covid-19-pandemic//
notes_C2: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/mali-declares-10-day-emergency-to-fight-covid-19/2082011#
notes_C4: "On 25 March 2020, the Government declared a state of health emergency and a curfew from 21h to 5h in the morning which came to complete a set of measures previously adopted including (...) the prohibition, until further notice, of social, sports, cultural and political groups of more than 50 people"    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427090758/https://reliefweb.int/report/mali/mali-coronavirus-covid-19-situation-report-no-1-reporting-period-25-march-08-april-2020
notes_H7: Mali's government says it has chosen to use the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine in its plan to initially immunise 4.2 million people. Health minister Fanta Siby said that the vaccination would first target medical staff, the elderly and those with co-morbidities. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210406040809/https://www.africanews.com/2021/01/22/mali-picks-astrazeneca-covid-19-vaccine-to-begin-vaccination-april//
notes_H3: http://malijet.com/a_la_une_du_mali/241897-covid-19-bonne-nouvelle-baisse-du-nombre-de-nouvelles-contaminat.html

name: Malta
notes_H1: on 9th March 2020, Maltese public health authorities set up a helpline, various web sites and an elevated coordinated public campaign.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074800/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/March/09/PR200435en.aspx
notes_H2: Swabs are generally available, even to asymptomatic or people wishing to swab on their wish.    https://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2020-03-24/local-news/Two-new-swabbing-hubs-to-open-in-Malta-tomorrow-6736221236
notes_C7: On 11th March 2021, the Maltese Government restricted travel to Gozo to only essential travel or people having a residence on the island.      Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210311061115/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2021/March/10/pr210501.aspx
notes_C1: Schools Start to re-open gradually.  Monday, April 12:   • Childcare centres, kindergartens, primary schools reopen   Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210409115241/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/abela-fearne-gauci-announce-covid-easing-measures-schools.863055
notes_H6: Mask is mandatory as soon as a person leaves home.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217080855/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/October/16/pr202014.aspx
notes_E2: From 13th March 2020, Government introduced, and maintained various narrow debt relief to households, from tax deferments to loan moratoria. This is in place up to at least 2021.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074334/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/March/14/pr200489.aspx  http://web.archive.org/web/20201217074531/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/moratorium-on-loan-repayments-to-extend-into-2021.839084
notes_E1: A wage supplement is introduced on 18th March 2020. This is committed to be provided at least till March 2021.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217072939/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/March/18/pr200520.aspx
notes_C3: Government reintroduces public event ban    http://web.archive.org/web/20201216100018/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/July/31/pr201473.aspx
notes_C6: Stay at home requirements are removed completely.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217083045/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/June/01/pr201038.aspx
notes_C8: Although the border closure is now lifted, travel to several countries remain banned throughout. The list of countries that travel is restricted to is very fluid and changes across time.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217072559/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/travel-ban-to-be-lifted-for-regions-in-italy-france-spain-hard-hit-by.801810
notes_H8: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217084731/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/May/22/pr200977en.aspx
notes_C2: As from 11th March 2021, in response to a surge in COVID-19 cases in Malta, the Maltese Government required all non-essential shops and service providers to shut down until at least 11th April.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210311061115/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2021/March/10/pr210501.aspx
notes_C4: Malta restricts gatherings to fewer than 10 people, then to 6.    source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217065445/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/national/105023/covid19_group_gatherings_in_public_spaces_reduced_to_10_people
notes_H7: As from 10th April 2021, The Maltese government announced that the vaccine programme is now extended. Apart from the three groups of people who are already being administered the vaccine (Key workers, clinically vulnerable groups, elderly groups), the vaccine is now broadly available to anyone who wishes to be vaccinated. For now this is limited to those aged over 50. This will be then extended to younger individuals.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210411070025/https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/chris-fearne-covid-19-vaccines-vaccination-strategy-malta-health.863757
notes_H3: Maltese authorities prepared for eventual outbreaks from January. In fact, when the first cases popped up in March, comprehensive contact tracing took place for each case.    http://web.archive.org/web/20201217080015/https://www.gov.mt/en/Government/DOI/Press%20Releases/Pages/2020/January/19/pr200063.aspx
notes_C5: Public transport operational as per normal, apart from some small requirements such as mask wearing.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201217070503/https://www.maltachamber.org.mt/en/malta-public-transport-releases-new-summer-schedule-with-436-additional-trips-per-day

name: Myanmar
notes_H1: On March 9th, the Ministry of Health and Sports launched an awareness campaign and COVID-19 tracking website.     They are:   "-publishing situation reports about Myanmar and other countries in the state-owned newspapers and the internet website of the Ministry (www.mohs.gov.mm) and social media pages (https://www.facebook.com/ MinistryOfHealthAndSportsMyanmar) and (https://www.facebook.com/ MyanmarCDC) , with taking response to the fake news  -coordination with relevant government agencies to lessen socioeconomic impacts resulted from COVID-19.  -awareness programmes with the use of handheld loudspeakers at the crowded places in Regions and States such as bus gates and markets, in cooperation with Myanmar Red Cross Society , civil society organizations and community based organizations."  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200604172504/https://www.globalnewlightofmyanmar.com/report-on-coronavirus-disease-2019-covid-19-3/    COVID-19 tracking website: https://web.archive.org/web/20200320234718/https://mohs.gov.mm/Main/content/publication/2019-ncov
notes_H2: Testing is also available at the following locations:  Air Cargo Terminal at Yangon International Airport: located on Pyay Road near the Than Pin Gone bus stop. It is located near the DHL Myanmar warehouse at the airport, which is searchable in Google Maps.  Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 9:00 a.m. until 11:00 a.m. with results available the next day by 9:30 a.m.  The cost of the PCR test is 200,000 MMK.  Telephone numbers: 094 4409 9941/094 4409 9942 (*We have received reports that phone inquiries may not be answered, but the facility remains open).  N Health: located in Yangon at the Tourist Burma Building on the corner of Maha Bandula St. and Sule Paya St. (near Sule Pagoda).  Swab collections for PCR tests occur daily from 8:00 a.m. until 10:00 a.m. with PCR results available within 24 hours.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322060444/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322152417/https://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/myanmar-reports-19-new-covid-19-infections-1-more-death-in-24-hours-121021900646_1.html
notes_C7: Trains: A limited number of train routes are operating.  Buses: Intra-provincial bus service has restarted but may be limited due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. City buses are operating as normal.  The Burmese government is actively enforcing rules regarding social distancing, curfews, movement restrictions, mask mandates, etc. Consequences can include fines or arrest for non-compliance.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125150817/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: The government of Myanmar ordered all schools, including private ones, to close from 26 August. The date for re-opening has not yet been announced  https://web.archive.org/web/20200909015440/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus
notes_H6: Since 13 May it has been compulsory for anyone going out in public in Myanmar to wear a facemask. Failure to wear one will result in a fine. This requirement is being enforced strictly and has led to the arrest of some offenders. https://web.archive.org/web/20200909015440/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/myanmar/coronavirus
notes_E2: This seems like it should be coded as 2. For example, according to the IMF, as of October 8 2020, there were measures in place including: exemptions and subsidies of household electricity charges (MMK 109 billion); deferment of income and commercial tax payments due in the second and third quarters of the fiscal year to end of FY 19/20. See https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  [accessed 19 October 2020, web archive unavailable]
notes_E1: E1 : updated to 1A from 1F as the relief is being provided to everyone in the "vulnerable" category.    In-kind and cash transfers to the *most vulnerable* population (MMK 325 billion)    Insured Fund for Workers: The Social Security Board, under the Ministry of Labor, Immigration and Population, will pay 40 percent of the salary to insured workers, as a family assistance fund, in accordance with the Social Security Law.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201029172716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M. that supersedes previous COVID-19 policies.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322060444/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: Residents of Yangon Region must abide by the following orders: 1.) stay at home unless going to/from work, 2.) employees of private organizations and businesses must telework (those working in banking and finance, gas stations, food and refrigeration services, production and manufacturing of pharmaceutical products, medical equipment production, and the distribution of drinking water and personal hygiene items are exempt), 3.) only one person per household allowed for grocery shopping, 3.) only two people per household allowed for medical treatment, 4.) a mask must be worn at all times when out of the home, 5.) only vehicles transporting people for one of the permitted activities are allowed to pass through other townships, 6.) in addition to the passenger(s), only one driver is allowed in a vehicle for the permitted activities,  http://web.archive.org/web/20210412175701/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: C8 : updated to 4 from 3 as the land and air borders are closed as per link below.    Effective March 30, the Burmese government will no longer allow international commercial passenger flights to land at any airport in Burma. This suspension will last through November 30  On March 19, the Burmese government announced the temporary suspension of entry and exit of foreign nationals through land borders.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109171739/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H8: More than 380000 people over the age of 65 years has been vaccinated  http://web.archive.org/web/20210412181318/https://www.mmtimes.com/news/more-380000-myanmar-receive-covid-19-vaccine.html
notes_C2: On the 25th of September the Ministry of Health and Sports issued an order effective 26th September that, people residing in 11 townships of the four state and regions are required for “Stay-at-Home” in order to effectively control the spread of the disease.   Those who need to perform their duties at government departments, banking services, filling stations, private-rum ports, communication businesses, food production, production and distribution of medical supplies and drinking water, factories of daily personal hygiene products and related businesses are excluded. Civil servants are to rotate on a 2-week for office attendance and 2-week on work-from-home basis.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201006141131/https://www.moi.gov.mm/moi:eng/announcements/1545
notes_C4: The military regime has instituted a ban on gatherings of five or more people, and a nationwide curfew from 8:00 P.M. until 4:00 A.M. that supersedes previous COVID-19 policies.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210322060444/https://mm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: A- Key workers, B- Clinically vulnerable groups  Myanmar receives free first batch of Covid-19, AstraZeneca’s vaccine manufactured by the Serum Institute of India. This is a gift from India to Myanmar  More than 110000 Healthcare workers and volunteers will be vaccinated as part of the initial phase. This will be followed by the government official and the elderly over the age of 65.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.deccanherald.com/international/myanmar-receives-first-batch-of-covid-19-vaccines-from-india-942168.html  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mmtimes.com/news/40pc-myanmars-population-be-vaccinated-against-covid-19-2021.html
notes_H3: http://web.archive.org/web/20210322152417/https://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/myanmar-reports-19-new-covid-19-infections-1-more-death-in-24-hours-121021900646_1.html
notes_C5: On the 25th of September the Ministry of Health and Sports issued an order effective 26th September that, people residing in 11 townships of the four state and regions are required for “Stay-at-Home” in order to effectively control the spread of the disease.   http://web.archive.org/web/20201006141131/https://www.moi.gov.mm/moi:eng/announcements/1545

name: Mongolia
notes_H2: Pretty low positive/tested rate: they might actually be testing even asymptomatic people:  http://archive.fo/AUUOy
notes_C7: [[D]ue to a rise in COVID-19 cases the Government of Mongolia has placed the country under lockdown and a “red all-out-readiness” status from 10 to 25 April. Internal travel, including within Ulaanbaatar, will be prohibited with exceptions only for emergency vehicles and funerals.' All domestic flights are cancelled.    https://archive.vn/79EyE
notes_C1: '[D]ue to a rise in COVID-19 cases the Government of Mongolia has placed the country under lockdown and a “red all-out-readiness” status from 10 to 25 April.' Schools are closed during lockdown.    https://archive.vn/79EyE
notes_H6: Everyone is required to wear a facemask in public places. Non-compliance is subjected to a fine up to MNT 50 000 (EUR 15).    https://archive.vn/0NGLd#selection-1133.0-1133.122
notes_E2: On March 27, a comprehensive set of fiscal measures for consideration has been proposed by the cabinet to protect vulnerable household and businesses and to support the economy. These include: (i) ... and (iv) an increase in credit guarantees to SMEs and soft loans from the development bank to cashmere producers. On April 13, Parliament approved tax exemption measures as proposed by the cabinet.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200723211732/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.mongolbank.mn/eng/news.aspx?tid=1&id=2489
notes_E1: Government on 2 Aug on how it is using international aid:  "For example, the child allowance was increased to MNT 100,000, funding for food purchases for low-income families was doubled, MNT 73,000 was provided to 73,000 people from 6.9 thousand low-income enterprises, and social welfare pensioners and permanent care recipients were provided. An additional MNT 768 billion has been spent so far, including an increase of MNT 100,000 in child benefits.  In addition, in order to protect the income of citizens, business entities and organizations, a total of 1 trillion 877.9 billion MNT of social insurance premiums, personal income and corporate income tax, its interest and fines were completely exempted. The Kovid-19 epidemic has created a total budget burden of 2.5 trillion MNT. "  http://archive.fo/E0dVy
notes_C3: '[D]ue to a rise in COVID-19 cases the Government of Mongolia has placed the country under lockdown and a “red all-out-readiness” status from 10 to 25 April.' Public events are not allowed during lockdown.    https://archive.vn/79EyE
notes_C6: '[D]ue to a rise in COVID-19 cases the Government of Mongolia has placed the country under lockdown and a “red all-out-readiness” status from 10 to 25 April.'    https://archive.vn/79EyE
notes_C8: The Government of Mongolia has decided to temporarily suspend entry of all passengers through all border checkpoints until 30 April 2020.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200517094042/http://embassyofmongolia.co.uk/?p=3265&lang=en
notes_H8: The State of All-Out-Readiness ends on Feb 23 and the curfew in the capital has been lifted. Citizens, businesses, and organizations have returned to normal work and life.   Link: https://archive.vn/5Y993
notes_C2: '[D]ue to a rise in COVID-19 cases the Government of Mongolia has placed the country under lockdown and a “red all-out-readiness” status from 10 to 25 April. ... Essential services such as grocery stores, pharmacies and hospitals will remain open throughout.'    https://archive.vn/79EyE
notes_C4: '[D]ue to a rise in COVID-19 cases the Government of Mongolia has placed the country under lockdown and a “red all-out-readiness” status from 10 to 25 April.' Gatherings are extremely restricted during lockdown.    https://archive.vn/79EyE

notes_C4: The SOPC (State of Public Calamity) will allow for the gradual resumption of the following activities:  - Private social events are permitted with up to 40 attendees  - Religious services are permitted at 50 percent capacity, up to 150 attendees  - Public and private institutions can conduct operations in conformance with social distancing and preventative measures including temperature checks, regular cleaning of facilities, ventilation, prohibition of sick staff entering facilities, and a limit of 40 people for events  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201115131525/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

notes_H3: Contact tracing for the first case in the country: The patient has mild symptoms, is in isolation at home and is undergoing clinical follow-up by the country's health authorities. notes_C5: "On September 7, Mozambique transitioned from a State of Emergency (SOE) to a State of Public Calamity (SOPC) [will be in place for an indefinite period]. During the SOPC the following prevention measures remain in effect:  (....)  Passenger limits for buses, vans, and other methods of public transportation"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201028113637/https://mz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028114857/https://www.dw.com/pt-002/covid-19-estado-de-calamidade-p%C3%BAblica-declarado-em-mo%C3%A7ambique/a-54822206

All schools, public places including beaches, shopping centers, and restaurants are closed until March 25th.  International flight arrivals have been suspended; however there are limited commercial departures to certain destinations.  https://archive.ph/7YQj1#selection-1817.72-1821.407

notes_H3: It seems like contract tracing is comprehensive rather than limited. Since the time the number of cases climbed steadily and reached 128 on 30 March, health services prioritised contact tracing to identify people to test – that is, people who had been in physical contact with infected and identified patients – while anybody who had been quarantined and showed symptoms suggestive of COVID-19 infection was also tested. This will be strictly enforced  Employers must reorganize their employees to work in shifts if the work requires physical presence, and to work from home for the next three weeks if it does not.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210125105334/https://theworldnews.net/mw-news/chakwera-address-jan-17-covid-19-demands-change-of-priorities-and-scaling-down-of-campaign-promises

notes_H7: A, B, C:  AstraZeneca  On April 6, the government announced that the vaccine is now available to everyone 18 years old and above. "I would like to inform the general public that we are now entering the second phase of COVID-19 vaccination whereby apart from those targeted in the first phase i.e. the health workers and other social workers, those aged 60 years and above and those with underlying conditions, the vaccination has been extended to everyone aged 18 years and above. My special appeal goes to those who by nature of their occupation interact with a lot of people on daily basis such as those working in banks, shops, vendors and those in the transport sector to come and get the vaccine. I would like to request everyone aged 18 years and above to utilize this opportunity to get vaccinated so that they are protected from COVID-19 severe disease, risk of hospitalization or death due to COVID-19. The vaccination exercise continues in all the Government and CHAM health facilities."    April 6, MOH post: https://web.archive.org/web/20210412000519/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fmalawimoh%2Fposts%2F3752144994840988    https://web.archive.org/web/20210411234712/https://www.nyasatimes.com/ministry-of-health-overwhelmed-with-turn-up-for-covid-19-vaccine/
